SPEECH.PARA: FOREST INDUSTRIES RESEARCH LEVY BILL 1993

This bill forms part of a package of legislation to establish and fund a Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation in partnership with industry. The purpose of this bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on wood produced in Australia which is delivered to a mill for processing in order to fund the Corporation.
The Corporation is to be established under the omnibus Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989.
There are two other bills in this package which provide for:
a charge on wood produced in Australia and exported from Australia as unprocessed wood; and
a charge on unprocessed wood and certain classes of primary processed forest products imported into Australia.

In addition, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Bill includes consequential amendments to the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 and the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989.

Mr President, the forest and wood products industry is of great significance to Australia's economy, generating significant employment and economic activity. The industry employs around 40,000 people, mostly in regional communities of Australia where there are limited alternative employment opportunities.

To date, the focus of the Australian forest industry has largely been on the domestic market where it has provided around two thirds of our consumption needs. Exports of forest and timber products have largely been confined to lower value woodchips and wood products which have undergone minimal processing. On the other hand, Australia is a significant importer of higher value pulp and paper products. Imports totalled some $2438 million in 1992-93, compared with exports of only some $775 million, resulting in a trade deficit of $1663 million. This amounted to around 11 per cent of the current account deficit for last year.

The Government is strongly committed to building competitiveness and expanding productivity of Australian industry, particularly our primary industries, whose contribution to exports underpins the economy. The Government's rural research policy is central to achieving this objective. The Commonwealth provides funding to encourage increased rural productivity and profitability through research and commercialisation of research findings.

Already the Commonwealth provides significant support to forest industry research and development in several ways: through direct funding to CSIRO Divisions of Forestry, Forest Products, and Wildlife and Ecology; to the Cooperative Research Centres for Temperate Hardwood Forestry and Hardwood Fibre and Paper Science; and through such programs as the National Pulp Mill Research Program and the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation's Agroforestry Program. Research into forestry and forest products is also supported by the State Governments and the forest industry.

However, there is no doubt that there is a need for an improvement in our forest and wood products research and development effort. This need has long been recognised by the Australian Forestry Council and by the industry.

In addition, all major reports on the forest industry, including the Resource Assessment Commission's 1992 Forest and Timber Inquiry, the National Plantations Advisory Committee and the ESD Working Group on Forest Use, have echoed the urgent need for an enhanced, better coordinated and better focused research effort. This is essential if we are to increase productivity and value-adding processing in our forests and wood products industries and to manage our forests in an ecologically sustainable manner.

The message is clear. We need to increase the level of research and to ensure that the focus is on nationally important, strategic issues. This does not mean diverting current funding or duplicating existing work. We need to lift our game overall.

The Government has therefore agreed, as a key initiative under the National Forest Policy Statement, to establish a Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation in partnership with industry. The Corporation and its commissioned research will be funded from contributions from the Commonwealth and industry.

Regulations have already been made establishing the Corporation from 1 January 1994 under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. As with other rural Research and Development Corporations, this Corporation will have a high degree of industry involvement and accountability: it will not be just another arm of Government. It will be set up as a body corporate with day to day autonomy and flexibility to operate in a manner similar to many commercial operations. Its purpose will be to provide national strategic leadership to industry research and development and act as a catalyst to stimulate research and development within industry.

The Corporation will identify national research priorities and assess research gaps. It will commission, administer and subsequently evaluate research into a broad range of areas relating to wood production, extraction, processing, economics and marketing.

Its charter will also include the ecological and environmental impacts of disturbance resulting from wood production, silviculture and management of native forests and plantations. The Corporation itself will not actually undertake any research. Organisations currently conducting forest industry research will be eligible to tender to carry out research on behalf of the Corporation.

Industry, through the National Association of Forest Industries as the representative organisation, will be closely involved in the selection of a Board of Directors for the Corporation. Procedures for selecting a Board, which are established under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, will ensure that the Board includes a broad range of expertise enabling it to address the full range of issues included in the charter of the Corporation.

The Corporation will be required to prepare 5 year research and development plans in consultation with industry which will outline the objectives, strategies and policies it intends to pursue. It will also be required to prepare Annual Operating Plans for each financial year, consistent with its 5 year plan.

The Corporation will also be required to prepare Annual Reports which will be tabled in Parliament and made available to industry for scrutiny. These will assess the Corporation's performance against the key elements identified in its strategic plans and contain sufficient information to enable industry to make a comprehensive assessment of the value of the research and development activities undertaken. The Chairperson of the Corporation will also be required to report directly to the Executive of the National Association of Forest Industries on an annual basis and be prepared to be questioned on the activities of the Corporation.

I repeat, Mr President, that the Commonwealth's intention in establishing the Corporation is to supplement the existing research effort rather than to replace it. There is a firm expectation that the existing research effort by the industry, both by private companies and the public forest management agencies, will be maintained or enhanced.

In order to raise sufficient funds to implement an effective research and development program under the Corporation, the forest and wood products industry has asked the Government to introduce a statutory levy on the domestic production of wood. The industry, including timber importers, have also requested a charge on imports of unprocessed wood and certain classes of primary processed forest products, including sawn timber, wood based panels, medium density fibreboard and hardboard.

I wish to emphasise, Mr President, that this is a charge on importers of wood and forest products, not on the overseas exporters. The Australian Timber Importers Federation, an affiliate of the National Association of Forest Industries, has recently expressed strong support for such a charge, recognising that importers, who stand to benefit from the research, should also contribute.

Of direct relevance to importers will be economic and marketing research, an area which will be specifically identified in the charter for the Corporation. Importers will benefit directly from research and development into fields such as expanding the demand for wood products in Australia, new market and product developments, fire related codes and standards and the use of timber in multiple storey construction.

In order to ensure that imports are treated no less favourably than domestic production, the legislation provides that the charge on imports of unprocessed wood is to be set at the same rate as the levy on domestic production. The legislation also provides that a conversion factor between unprocessed wood and classes of processed wood, which has been agreed with industry, will be applied to the levy to determine a rate of charge for primary processed wood products imported into Australia. The conversion factors will ensure that equivalent rates apply between imports and domestic production.

To ensure that importers benefit from the research activities undertaken by the Corporation, the legislation provides explicitly that funds which have been raised from the charge on imports must be directed to research and development which will be of relevance to the timber importing industry.

The Minister for Resources has been assured that introduction of the levy is fully consistent with Australia's obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the Closer Economic Relations Agreement with New Zealand.

The Commonwealth will provide $1 for every $2 from the domestic industry up to a maximum of 0.25 per cent of the Gross Value of Production of the industry. The basis of the 1 : 2 funding arrangement arises from the structure of the forest-related industry. Half of the industry has a primary industry focus (tree production, small rural sawmills), while the other half has a manufacturing orientation. Commonwealth funding is intended to match the rural half of the industry contribution, consistent with arrangements for research and development in other rural industries. This is also in recognition that the Commonwealth already provides significant support to the other sectors of industry through other research programs. However, the Commonwealth will not match funds raised from the import charge.

Operative rates of the levy and charges to be contributed by industry will be set by regulation on the basis of advice from industry. Under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, before the Minister for Resources makes any recommendation to the Governor-General on the operative rate of levy or to the classes of leviable products or changes to these, the Minister is required to take into consideration any relevant advice from any prescribed organisation, in this case, the National Association of Forest Industries.

Industry is still consulting on the operative rate at which the levy and charges are to be introduced. The legislation sets a maximum rate for a class of wood of 0.5 per cent of its average value to ensure that no one sector of the forest industry bears a significantly greater responsibility for industry contributions than others, and indeed, that the industry overall is not levied excessively. The Minister for Resources has been advised by the National Association of Forest Industries that they expect to recommend a rate lower than this for some sectors. For every 0.1 per cent, the rate would be in the order of 4 and 6 cents per cubic metre of unprocessed wood.

It will be up to industry to decide whether the revenue raised by the levy and charges, together with the Commonwealth's contribution, is providing the Corporation with the resources to increase the research effort to the appropriate level.
The Commonwealth will, in a sense, be acting as the agent of industry to ensure that the levy and charges are applied in a comprehensive and equitable way.

The levies and charges will be collected in accordance with the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991. These, together with the Commonwealth contribution, will be paid into a separate account under the administration of the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation.

This particular bill relates to the imposition of a levy on unprocessed wood which is delivered to a mill and will take effect from 1 January 1994. The bill provides that different levy rates may apply to different classes of wood. The levy will be payable by the operator of the mill to which the wood is delivered.

Industry has requested that different rates of levy apply to four classes of wood—hardwood sawlogs, softwood sawlogs, hardwood pulplogs and softwood pulplogs. These will be based on the average value for that class of wood. In the case of unprocessed wood which is produced in Australia and exported, a charge at the same rates as the levies imposed by this bill will be imposed by the Forest Industries Research Export Charge Bill 1993 when the wood is exported.
Industry has also requested that provision be made for flexibility of levy rates within the forest sectors. The bill provides for this.

Contributions from the domestic industry are expected to raise around $180,000 in the last six months of 1993/94, rising to $700,000 in 1994/95. In providing funding for the Corporation, the Commonwealth will outlay about $90,000 in 1993/94 and around $350,000 in 1994/95. The Commonwealth has committed a total of $4.25 million for the period up to 1995/96 after which a review will be held with industry on the effectiveness of the Corporation.

Mr President, I am pleased to be able to bring these bills before the Senate. They mark an important new phase in forest industry research and development which will enable existing research activities to be better focused and coordinated. The establishment of the Corporation will be a sound investment in the future of the industry and should lead to significant advances in forest production and our ability to add value to our forest products. This, in turn, will help to build competitiveness, both internationally as well as with other materials, and to expand the productive capacity of our forest industries.
At the same time, it will also provide a sound framework for achieving the objectives of the National Forest Policy Statement for research and development.
I commend the bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum to the bills.
FOREST INDUSTRIES RESEARCH EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1993

The purpose of this bill is to provide for the imposition of a charge on unprocessed wood produced in Australia and exported, in order to raise funds for a Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation.

The bill enables changes to the operative rate of charge and for changes to the classes of unprocessed wood to which charges apply to be set by regulation. Prior to the Minister making any recommendation to the Governor-General on the operative rate of charge or to the classes of leviable products, the Minister is to take into consideration any relevant advice from the National Association of Forest Industries and any other prescribed organisation. Operative rates for each class of wood which are set by regulation must fall within the legislated maximum rate of 0.5 per cent of the average value of production of that class of wood.
The operative rates of charge for unprocessed wood exported from Australia will be set at the same rates as those charged under the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill 1993.
I commend the bill to honourable senators.
FOREST INDUSTRIES RESEARCH IMPORT CHARGE BILL 1993

The purpose of this bill is to provide for the imposition of a charge on the import of unprocessed wood and certain classes of primary processed wood into Australia, in order to raise funds for a Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation.

The bill provides for changes to the operative rate of charge and for changes to the classes unprocessed wood and forest products to which the charges apply to be set by regulation. Prior to the Minister making any recommendation to the Governor-General on the operative rate of charge or to the classes of leviable products, the Minister is to take into consideration any relevant advice from the National Association of Forest Industries and any other prescribed organisation. Operative rates for each class of wood or forest product which are set by regulation must fall within the legislated maximum rate of 0.5 per cent of the average value of production of that particular class.

To ensure that importers benefit from the research activities undertaken by the Corporation, amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, will provide explicitly that funds which have been raised from the charge on imports must be directed to research and development which will be of relevance to the timber importing industry.

The operative rates of charge for unprocessed wood imported into Australia will be set at the same rates as those charged under the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill 1993. For every 0.1 per cent, the levy rate would be in the order of between 4 and 6 cents per cubic metre of unprocessed wood.
Based on this rate, the operative rates for processed wood imported into Australia would be between 10 and 15 cents per cubic metre.
I commend the bill to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993. At the outset, I must say that the coalition will not be opposing this bill and has no amendments to the bill.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators would be aware that, as part of the budget, the government announced it would be modifying the pharmaceutical benefits scheme arrangements for general patients. Under present arrangements there is a two-tier safety net limit for general patients and patients pay $15.90 per script until the first threshold of $309.90 is reached. They then pay $2.60 a script until the second threshold of $361.50 is reached. Beyond this threshold, drugs are provided free of charge.

Passage of this bill will mean that from 1 January 1994 there will be a single safety net threshold for general patients of $400—that is, 25 scripts at $16 each. Beyond this threshold, there will be a fee of $2.60 per script. That means that drugs will no longer be available to general patients free of charge. The increase in the safety net limit and the removal of access to free drugs is estimated to save $12.4 million in 1993-94, $32 million 1994-95, $33.4 million in 1995-96 and $34.9 million in 1996-97.

With the ageing of the population and new drugs being developed, the cost to government of operating the PBS is growing at an alarming rate. In 1992-93 the cost of operating the pharmaceutical benefits scheme increased by 25 per cent to $1.5 billion. The Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) in his second reading speech also highlighted the problem of stockpiling of medicines.

In 1992 more than 70 per cent of the annual prescriptions for general patients were supplied in the last two months of the safety net period. I think that these points represent a pretty compelling argument for a continued co-payment beyond the safety net limit. It is also important to point out that the arrangements for pensioners and veterans and other recipients of drugs at a concessional rate are not affected.

While speaking about the matter of pharmaceuticals, I take the opportunity to raise a number of other important issues. Firstly, generic prescribing has come under increased scrutiny in recent times following a couple of items on the 7.30 Report on the Wingham pharmacist Mr Stuart Keene.

The issue was the subject of considerable discussion at the 31 August hearing of Senate Estimates Committee C. What emerged from this discussion, apart from the questionable approach of the Health Insurance Commission in dealing with Mr Keene, was that the government has a minimum pricing policy which does not have the legislative support it deserves. This is obviously a very sensitive issue. Any changes in the area will need to be based on very widespread consultation. However, there is a compelling argument for giving patients greater freedom of choice when they receive pharmaceuticals from pharmacists.

Unless doctors have clearly indicated that there is to be no substitution, pharmacists should be able to talk to patients about the choice available between a brand name and a generic drug, in the cases where a generic drug is available, with obvious due and proper regard for bioequivalents. As the law stands at the moment, this can occur only if the pharmacist rings a doctor seeking his or her permission to offer the generic drug.

In additional material that was provided to me after the Senate estimates committee hearing that I referred to earlier, the government recognised that further action might be warranted in regard to generic prescribing. I find it fascinating that the government can have a minimum pricing policy which involves the use of generic drugs and does not put the legislative backing in place that will be needed if it is to be effective.
The summary that was provided to me after the Senate estimates committee says:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the concerns of the medical profession and the fact that State law is important in this area, the Government's approach to encouraging generics via the 1990 policy change was the most appropriate way of progressing the use of generics at that time.

Given that there has been a significant increase in the use of generics since then, and that concerns about quality have been dealt with, it is now appropriate to consider moving to generic substitution as a way of making further progress.

I know that this is a thorny issue for the government to deal with, but I urge it to take courage. If it means anything by its minimal pricing policy it should get on with the job. I would be very interested in any further comments that the minister responsible could add to this summary, in particular in regard to what substantive action the government intends to take.

PARA.TAB: Another important issue that relates to the question of pharmaceuticals is the role of pharmacists, which I believe is evolving and will evolve even further over time. Community pharmacists have traditionally been regarded merely as suppliers and dispensers of medication. It is pretty apparent to anyone in contact with the pharmacy profession that their training fits them with skills to make a wider contribution to community health.

The fourth issues paper of the national health strategy on pharmaceutical drug use in Australia and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs report entitled Prescribed health have both made very important recommendations on the issue of the wider involvement of pharmacists in managing drug use. Having formerly been a shadow minister for the aged, I am well aware of the problems of pharmaceutical use by the elderly—both those living in their homes and those in institutionalised care. Elderly people today are often faced with a bewildering array of drugs and there are problems of both non-compliance and over prescribing. I have recently raised these matters with the AMA.

I know that the AMA shares concerns about the over-medication of the elderly. I hope that action can be taken by the professions, including the pharmacy profession, to improve the quality of prescribing and the control over prescribing in some of these areas where, clearly, it is a bit out of hand. I believe that a community pharmacist could make a valuable contribution as part of a team of health professionals responsible for managing the care of our elderly in nursing homes. I am not suggesting that the doctors concerned should not be involved. In fact, I often think the local GP is not as involved as he or she might be in the care of an elderly patient who becomes resident in a nursing home. But the professions together have a shared role here.

I think it is time that the government addressed itself seriously to this issue. The House of Representatives standing committee report has been available for 10 months. This issue is part of the broader one of the medical and other professions working more closely together. As I said earlier, there are a number of ways in which this could occur. One very practical way would be to establish computer software prescribing packages for doctors. There are software packages for pharmacists which demonstrate the prescriptions made available to a patient over several years so that, when a new prescription comes in, a flag comes up on the computer suggesting where there is likely to be a problem between scripts.

By the doctor producing scripts electronically, the job of the pharmacist would be much easier since there would be no difficulty in reading scripts and, thus, the safety of the patient would be guaranteed. In addition, the doctor would have a record of other patients' previous pharmaceutical use, so that any future prescribing could take this history into account. The system we have at the moment does allow pharmacists to pick up a problem, but it is important that the doctor who does the prescribing should know of the contraindications before a new script is issued.

Proposals of this nature have so far been the subject of relatively little public debate and certainly deserve greater attention. I commend them to the minister, who I am glad to see is now in the chamber, for his attention. This is an issue which is of great seriousness to the wellbeing of patients in this country as well as being an issue of importance to revenue. I hope that, in the interests of good medical care, more leadership might be taken by the government in this area of prescribing, the role of the pharmacy profession and the interrelationship of the pharmacy and the medical professions. As I said at the outset, the opposition is not opposing this bill and we have no amendments to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The sole purpose of the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 that is before us today is to alter the structure of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme safety net for non-pensioners. At present, the PBS safety net for non-pensioners, called general patients, has two levels. After spending $312.30 on pharmaceuticals, a general patient is entitled to pharmaceuticals at the concessional rate of $2.60 per prescription. This continues until a further $52 is spent in a year. A general patient then qualifies for the pharmaceutical benefits entitlement card and is entitled to free pharmaceuticals.

PARA.TAB: This bill abolishes the two-tiered structure and fixes one safety net at $400 a year, after which a general patient becomes eligible for a safety net concession card and can receive drugs at the concessional rate for the rest of that year. The pharmaceutical benefits entitlement card is abolished and general patients will no longer be eligible to receive free pharmaceuticals after this bill is passed.

The current two-tiered structure was introduced in the 1986 federal budget and, at the time, the government said it was changing the PBS in order to protect people suffering from some sort of chronic health problem. In November 1986 in this chamber, Senator Grimes, representing the Minister for Health, talked of the government's desire to provide specific assistance to those deemed to be most disadvantaged—the chronically ill, the high drug user or the family with one or more chronically ill members.

Similarly, the then Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, said the new scheme was being introduced to protect the chronically ill by imposing a limit on what they must pay for their pharmaceuticals. In short, the government made a good deal of fuss six years ago about how wonderful and caring it was to think up and introduce this structure.

Answering a question on the changes in November 1986, Senator Grimes gave the example of a family with two asthmatic children requiring five prescriptions monthly for each child at the then cost of $600 a year. He pointed out that, under the changes the government was introducing, the same family would pay about $183 to reach the 25 prescriptions threshold, then nothing for the remainder of the year, a saving of over $400. Senator Grimes went on to say that this example was `quite typical of the disadvantaged family group who will be protected under this new scheme'.

Speaking on the budget back then, Dr Blewett called the scheme `a long overdue reform', saying that it was aimed at providing sufferers of chronic illnesses and other high volume users with increased protection against the high cost of pharmaceuticals. Dr Blewett went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . those with chronic conditions and those in need of heavy medication will be protected as they have never been protected in the past. The rest of us who, on the whole, use less medication, will accept our contribution to containing health costs and to better protection for the chronically ill.

If we look through the Hansard database we see what Senator Crowley, the Minister for Family Services, had to say about this bill currently before the Senate. What did she have to say about its effect on low income families? She was particularly vocal back in 1986. She supported very strongly then the putting in place of the safety net. In September 1986, speaking in the chamber on the bill which introduced the safety net, she said:

People can bear very considerable costs if they have a chronic illness, or because of the stage in their life cycle. For example, families with young children may need a quite considerable number of prescriptions in a year.
She went to say:

Essentially the Government recognises that the principal problems with pharmaceutical benefits charges are suffered by people with chronic illness. It has recognised this by building in a safety net . . .

So I have to question what Senator Crowley is saying now. What has changed since 1986? Does the government no longer consider that the brunt of charges for pharmaceuticals is borne by people with chronic illness? Are people with chronic illness suddenly using fewer drugs? Has their need for pharmaceuticals magically reduced? Of course not.

PARA.TAB: What has changed is that the government has now decided that the safety net is costing it too much money and wants to cut back on PBS expenditure, regardless of the impact on people with chronic health problems. This is just another cost cutting exercise in this budget. I would like to hear Senator Crowley try to justify it.

The government says that it has had to take this action because of a blow out in 1992 in the number of prescriptions to general patients under this free safety net. It says that there has been an increase of more than 150 per cent over the previous year. The Democrats do not dispute that there are problems with ever increasing PBS expenditure. I agree that something needs to be done to rein it in. But this concentration on the costs of PBS means that we tend to overlook the significant benefits which flow from it.The PBS is certainly expensive, but let us not forget that it has been highly effective in controlling drug prices. Without it the national drug bill would be considerably higher because, in effect, the PBS stands as a very necessary intermediary between consumers and the very powerful pharmaceutical industry.

What concerns me about this bill is that once again the government seems to be unable to see any way of addressing increases in PBS expenditure other than by hitting the chronically ill. The Democrats have always opposed moves to reduce the PBS expenditure by tackling the problem from the consumer or patient end of the chain. We have taken this approach for three reasons. Firstly, the demand for drugs is essentially inelastic. That is, it does not respond to price signals. People either need the drugs to make them better or they do not need the drugs. They are not an optional extra or luxury which people just tend to take or not to take, to elect to purchase or not to purchase, depending on whether the price is right. In other words, all that happens when fees are introduced, or access to free PBS drugs is restricted, is that low income earners end up spending a higher proportion of their income on pharmaceuticals.

Secondly, there are strong arguments to support the notion that the issue of polypharmacy cannot be resolved by increasing patient contributions. Thirdly, there is convincing evidence to suggest that the demand for drugs is primarily driven by the promotional activities of the pharmaceutical industry and the prescription practices of medical practitioners and not by the patients themselves.

For example, the minister in his second reading speech says that there has been a considerable stockpiling under the safety net with more than 70 per cent of the annual number of prescriptions being supplied in the last two months of the safety net period. But it is not the patients who are writing these prescriptions. Surely, if this sort of stockpiling is occurring, the government should be looking not only at the behaviour of the consumers—are they stockpiling prescriptions somehow that the doctors have written over a period of time without any medical supervision whatsoever?—but also at the prescribing practices of these people's doctors.

Even aside from these three concerns, I still do not understand why, if the government is so concerned about expenditure increases under the free safety net by general patients, it could not look at some sort of means test to ensure that at least the chronically ill people on low incomes can continue to be protected. A cost of $2.60 per prescription probably does not sound very much to some of us, but we are talking about chronically ill people who have already spent $400 in that year on drugs. This rate of expenditure suggests that these are people who are likely to need several prescriptions a month, if not a week.

Let us take Dr Blewett's example of some six years ago: the family with two children with chronic asthma who require five prescriptions per child per month. Under this new scheme, that family, which would have received drugs free after reaching the safety net, will now be paying out an extra $26 a month for drugs. That is perhaps not a lot for a family with a reasonable income but it is potentially quite a burden for a family which is already struggling to make ends meet.

I really question the basic fairness of making chronically ill people pay more for their drugs, especially when those people are living on a low income. I do not see why the government could not have looked at putting some sort of means test into the free safety net. Surely it would not have been too difficult to do. At least it would have ensured a measure of protection for people on low incomes with chronic health problems. I would like to know—perhaps the minister can tell us during the committee stage—whether or not such an option was considered at any stage and, if it was considered, why it was not adopted.

Over a number of years the Democrats have also called for a full independent review of the PBS because of our concern that reform measures adopted by the government continue to be directed almost entirely at the issue of price, rather than addressing the range of other factors which are crucial to PBS expenditure. Some of those factors include: the role of doctors, particularly GPs, in dispensing drugs; the role of promotional advertising within the pharmaceutical industry in relation to cost effectiveness of prescribing by doctors; the general lack of consumer awareness about pharmaceuticals and limited access to independent medications information; the limited specialist medical knowledge about geriatric prescribing; and alternative forms of therapy. Indeed, what is there that we can do without relying constantly on drugs? What other community services are required to reduce the reliance of people on medication? It is time that the government seriously addressed these issues rather than continuing to put the onus back on the patients.

Over the past few years the government has introduced three major measures to rein in PBS expenditure: increased patient contributions, such as this bill; pensioner co-payments; and the minimum pricing policy. The net effect of these measures, at a time of chronic economic recession, has been to transfer a substantial part of increased pharmaceutical costs directly to the consumers. In short, the government's strategy is to cut back PBS expenditure and focus almost exclusively on the consumer, either through the introduction of some sort of price signal or by way of education programs which urge patients to be wise, responsible and vigilant consumers. Very few government strategies are focused on the prescribing practice of GPs or the often aggressive marketing activities of pharmaceutical companies.

I do not want to see the government use its monopoly power under the PBS to drive manufacturers to the wall, but equally, I do not want to see the government continue to go down this path of cutting PBS expenditure by transferring costs to consumers with little regard for the consequences. The Democrats do not think the measures outlined in this bill before the Senate do anything positive for the health of Australians and we will not be supporting this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will first address Senator Newman's point on generic substitution. I heard the beginning of her speech as I left my office. I did not get to hear all that she said as I was on my way to the chamber.
—I will send you an autographed copy.

—I thank Senator Newman very much. I can hardly wait. My advisers have given me a note about what Senator Newman said. I have written to the states on the matter already. As Senator Newman would appreciate, we need the cooperation of the states to go down this route because they do control the practice of pharmacists in their dispensing facilities. They also, of course, control the registration and practice of the medical profession. So we will need their cooperation.

PARA.TAB: I am of the view that it is time for change on this question and that where pharmacists are certain of the bioequivalence of one brand as against another, substitution should be permitted provided there is no note to the contrary on a prescription from the prescribing doctor. So I have written to the states on that matter. We are talking with the AMA and the pharmaceutical industry and pharmacist organisations as well. I am going to try to push this as fast as I can. Hopefully, we can have some cooperation during the course of 1994.

It will require a change of legislation in every state, so it is something that state ministers will have to agree on. We will be pursuing it. I am not certain that it is on the agenda for the meeting on 1 December. If it is not, I will certainly make sure it is at least referred to so I can get some idea of their intentions. My understanding from preliminary discussions with a number of states, however, is that there is little opposition to proceeding down this path. So I am hopeful that I will be able to report progress in the Senate perhaps after that meeting on 1 December.

In respect of the contribution of Senator Lees, I think she was primarily talking about elasticity in demand and was saying that demand was inelastic. Unfortunately, I think she also undid her own case by quoting from the second reading speech. The figure that she used that in 1992 more than 70 per cent of the annual number of prescriptions for general patients are being supplied in the last two months of the safety net period does suggest that demand is anything but inelastic.

Indeed, in 1992 the use of medicines under the free safety net for general patients increased by more than 150 per cent over the previous year. With an ageing population and the development of new drugs, the costs of operating the PBS are going up at, in my view, quite frightening rates every year. In 1992-93, for instance, costs increased by 25 per cent over the previous financial year to around $1 1/2 billion.

That cost is eventually borne by the taxpayer. It has to be our responsibility to try to do something about it. Unfortunately, there is no such thing as a cheap breakthrough in the discovery of new drugs these days and that means that the price of pharmaceuticals being asked for by the companies is very great indeed.

One thing that Senator Lees did not refer to which I think is pretty important is that drugs in Australia are cheaper than in any comparable country. We have had a first class record in resisting some of the more outrageous claims of the pharmaceutical companies in trying to keep costs to within a reasonable degree. Even having done that, we are still seeing significant increases in costs every year. I think it is the government's responsibility to look at any way or means that it can find to try to get that increase under control.

When I come into the chamber on a day like this to defend the kind of measure that is before us, it is not with some pleasure, glee or glint in my eye; it is not something that I am extremely happy about. I think it is just one of those necessary functions of government. Taxpayers are always going to look to us to try to control and contain costs. We have a duty to do so.

It is also the case that Australia has to look at what it can afford, not simply at what it would like. I think we would all like not to have to introduce measures like this—it would be terrific—but I do not think we can sustain the kinds of increases to which I have referred over any lengthy period. If we cannot sustain them, then the kinds of measures that would have to be taken at the end of the day would be far more horrific than anything that is contemplated at the moment.

In relation to the charge of $2.60 after the $400 limit, Senator Lees says that that will be a lot of money for families and she quoted Dr Blewett's example of six years ago. By the way, any GP looking at the latest Asthma Foundation booklet on asthma management would not have the same prescribing practices, because asthma management has changed dramatically in that six years and will, I hope, continue to change. But that is only a debating point because chronic illness is not only asthma and, obviously, $2.60 for families is a struggle. We have to understand that, in that whole argument of containing costs, if the average cost of those drugs is approximately $19 then at $2.60 the taxpayer is still giving a very heavy subsidy. In fact, it is an extraordinarily heavy subsidy.

While I do not take particular pride in ever defending measures of this kind and while they do not give me any warm feeling inside, I do know that, unless governments are prepared to keep the cost of pharmaceuticals under constant review and make certain that we keep the overall costs under some sort of control, they will romp away from us in the way they have in, say, the United States and some European countries. When that happens, access to drugs will not be as easy as it is for Australians today. It is going to get more and more difficult. While it may be with a heavy heart, it is nonetheless the duty of government to do what is contained in this bill.

That the bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inadvertently forgot to respond to a point that Senator Lees raised about some kind of extra means test. The government does not have such a plan in mind.

PARA.TAB: I think it is worth noting that as at December 1992 there were 5.6 million card holders in Australia. That number increased by a further 200,000 from 1 July with the changes that the government made to the seniors card, which Senator Lees would be aware of, in respect of incomes and assets testing. That there are 5.8 million card holders—that is, a third of Australia is able to access the cheapest pharmaceuticals—is evidence that we have a means test that works extraordinarily well. The government would not plan to change that.

It was acknowledged during the last election campaign—and even before it—that over time the number of people holding seniors cards is more likely to increase. I think there will be further measures down that route as funds permit. In the next few years I think there will be further changes, especially if the economy takes off in the way that we all hope. While the government is not planning any new or special measures in respect of means testing, I think the ones that we have and have extended work pretty well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) for his comments. I acknowledge that there are some 5.6 million card holders. The concerns of the Australian Democrats rest with many people in rural Australia who do not qualify for any pension or benefits at all, yet have incomes that, in many cases, are negative. We also have a concern that those people who move off unemployment benefit and into casual or low paid employment and then lose their entitlements will face difficulties, particularly if there is chronic illness in the family. That was the Democrats' reason for looking at some sort of means testing on this issue.

PARA.TAB: I will ask the minister a couple of specific questions. DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1993THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 September, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill 1993. I will address parts 3, 4, 5, 6 and 8 of the first bill, as well as the second bill. My colleague Senator Tambling will be addressing the other parts of the first bill, including a particular concern that the coalition has with clause 4.

PARA.TAB: At the outset, I should say that the coalition will not be seeking to oppose the passage of these bills. For the most part, the bills are of a straightforward nature, making technical or minor changes, including two minor amendments relating to nursing homes, which eliminate clauses that have become obsolete. However, I intend to raise a number of important points regarding the way the changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act have been put forward.

Part 3 of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 amends the Health Insurance Act: to ensure that not more than one pathology authority controls a pathology laboratory, so that there can be no Medicare benefit double dipping; to require pathology authorities, in circumstances where practitioners leave an authority, to retain request forms for pathology services; to impose penalties on pathology authorities for providing pathology request forms which are different from the approved forms; to ensure that a pathology authority which is partly or wholly owned by a state, territory or public authority is not an approved pathology authority; to allow the minister to review, after a period of 12 months, a determination allowing an approved pathology authority to operate additional collection centres—another amendment extends to an authority a right of review of the minister's decision; and, to make a minor change to the way in which licence fees are reimbursed to an authority if permission to operate a collection centre is cancelled. These are all technical amendments and are not contentious. The fact that they are before the Senate today is a reflection of the rushed nature of previous legislation in this area.

Further technical amendments are made in relation to the Hearing Services Act in part 4 of the main bill, and to the National Health and Medical Research Council Act in part 6 of the main bill. Part 5 amends the National Health Act to allow pharmacists who relocated before the 1990 restructuring arrangements to continue to supply pharmaceutical benefits. The amendments will also allow the secretary, where approval is granted in the above circumstances, to cancel approval for the earlier premises. Again, these are technical amendments only. I understand that the Pharmacy Guild has not raised any particular concerns with them.

I turn now to the most substantial parts of the legislation before us, those making changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act. Among other things, these changes will facilitate the introduction of complementary state and territory therapeutic goods legislation, the first of which may be in place early in 1994; give effect to an international convention on the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, which allows for mutual exchange of manufacturing information, thus removing the need for overseas inspections by the importing country; extend the definition of `authorised person'—persons called on to assist the Therapeutic Goods Administration in investigating breaches of the act—to include members of the Australian Federal Police; and allow the Therapeutic Goods Administration to evaluate goods which, under transitional provisions of the 1989 act, were listed or registered without evaluation.

I wish to place on the public record my strong reservations about two of the changes I have just outlined. The first is the framework being set up for complementary Commonwealth-state legislation. The coalition strongly supports the proposal that the Commonwealth and the states work together to produce complementary therapeutic goods legislation.

We saw the consequences of a failure of Commonwealth-state cooperation highlighted in Victoria a couple of months ago. I refer to the case of the woman registered as a beauty therapist in Victoria who injected silicon into the noses, faces and breasts of women. Because this woman was not trading interstate and was not incorporated, she was slipping through a legislative loophole. The federal Therapeutic Goods Act essentially deals with the importing and exporting of therapeutic devices and their supply and manufacture.

Since the business of the beauty therapist is not incorporated and she trades in one state—and unless she is found to be importing silicon—the Commonwealth is powerless to act against her. In the end, the Therapeutic Goods Administration has finally been moved to recommend that injectable silicon be classed as a poison. However, the situation could have been dealt with more quickly and more effectively if adequate, complementary Commonwealth-state legislation had been in place.

In the meantime, the consequences of the actions of that beauty therapist have been serious. Women who have been injected are suffering pain and, in the cases of breast injection, have an inability to breastfeed. Research indicates that the longer term consequences can be very serious, requiring corrective surgery.

I said in July that the Commonwealth and the states should work together to overcome loopholes in the law which allow therapists injecting silicon to continue to operate. I also said that, having made a commitment to introduce complementary state therapeutic goods legislation in 1991, states have been tardy in implementing this promise.

It should be clear that the coalition is supportive of the idea of complementary therapeutic goods legislation. But if such a proposal is to be successful, it must be done in a true spirit of consultation. I know that the last meeting of Commonwealth-state health ministers confirmed agreement on complementary therapeutic goods legislation. Since that meeting the Commonwealth has moved on and developed the federal legislation that we have before us today.

It has been suggested to my office by the Therapeutic Goods Administration that the Commonwealth has moved first because it was being pressured to produce a framework for the states to work with. That might well be the case. However, even if it is the case, it does not justify the arrogant way in which the government has introduced these changes.

Given the importance of this legislation to the planning processes being undertaken by the states, I was amazed to find that they were not provided with advance copies of the legislation. At the very least, as a matter of courtesy, health ministers in each state and territory should have been advised of the introduction of the legislation and provided with a copy of the amendments. It was the arrogant approach of the Commonwealth which prompted the Victorian Minister for Health to put out a press statement entitled, `Tehan slams high-handed federal approach'.

As Marie Tehan said in her statement, every state and territory should have been offered a realistic opportunity to comment on the amendments. After all, the Victorian Minister for Health tried to make the Health Ministers Council a cooperative forum. She tried to suggest to the world that it was in everybody's interest that that forum works well. I agree that it is very important to us all, but action speaks louder than words and the action over this legislation is not all that crash hot.

It is not only the states and territories that have not been adequately consulted on the provisions concerning Commonwealth-state complementary legislation. The Nutritional Foods Association was not informed of the introduction of the amendments, yet this association has a vital interest in these changes. The association represents a range of interests in the nutritional foods area from retailers to distributors to sponsors. Many nutritional food retailers are sole traders and unincorporated companies. They are obviously very interested in the form that the complementary state legislation will take. I understand that at this point Victoria is the closest to producing model state legislation.

Given the lack of consultation shown by the Commonwealth, I hope that the states will work closely with the Nutritional Foods Association and any other relevant organisations as they develop their legislation. It might demonstrate to the Commonwealth how much more can be achieved by cooperation than by taking the attitude of `big brother and sister know best'.
I would also warn the minister that the coalition will not be so tolerant in the future when it finds that key interests in the industry have not been adequately consulted.

The second concern I wish to place on the public record relates to changes to the evaluation of goods under the transitional arrangements of the 1989 act. In recognition of the enormous number of products already on the market when the Therapeutic Goods Act was introduced, these products were grandfathered into the register. The volume of goods already on the market when the act was established meant it would have taken years to evaluate each good.

The legislation before us seeks to clarify that, where goods have been listed or registered without evaluation, the secretary may, if he or she thinks appropriate, notify a sponsor that an evaluation of the goods will take place to establish whether or not the goods should remain listed or registered. I have been advised by the Therapeutic Goods Administration that this change has been necessary to clarify a provision in the original act.

Apparently, the Australian Government Solicitor's Office has suggested that, despite a proviso contained in the second reading speech of the Therapeutics Goods Bill 1989, it is open to a court to read that each and every product on the market at the commencement of the act was required to be evaluated or assessed before it could be entered into the register as a grandfathered product. My concern is that there is no indication in the legislation of the guidelines which will be used by the Therapeutic Goods Administration in deciding why a particular good will be singled out for evaluation. It effectively confers a significant discretionary power on the Therapeutic Goods Administration.

This could potentially be used as a revenue raising activity since full evaluation fees will be payable by the sponsor of the good as a means of singling out a particular sponsor for unfair attention. Under the act as it stands, grandfathered goods can already be singled out for evaluation. I have been informed that an evaluation would take place in the event that, for example, adverse reports about a grandfathered product are received, or, if, in the course of dealing with an application by a sponsor of grandfathered goods to amend its product in some way, it became apparent that a full evaluation was necessary.

Although I do not wish to hold up this particular legislation on this point, I believe that it is a weakness of the primary act that the specific circumstances leading to the evaluation of grandfathered goods are not clearly set out in the act for all to judge. I invite the minister to address this point when he or she, depending on who takes this bill through, concludes the second reading debate.

In conclusion, the coalition will not be opposing the bills before us. I have put on record the concerns which the coalition has with some aspects of the legislation. I look forward to the response of the minister to these. As I mentioned at the start of my speech, Senator Tambling will be highlighting a particular concern which the coalition has with clause 4 of the main bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will begin by firstly looking at Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The Democrats really have concerns about only one specific aspect of this bill, so I will not be taking up very much of the Senate's time.

PARA.TAB: The bill makes a number of mainly technical amendments to several bills within the health, housing and community services portfolio. Part 2 makes several amendments to the Disability Services Act 1986 and it is clause 4 in this part which is of concern to us.

Clause 4 amends section 14J of the Disability Services Act. Under 14G of that act, the minister can make a declaration stating that an organisation which is eligible for government funding is not meeting the standards under the act and is, in effect, in breach of the conditions of its funding grant. The declaration can be made only after a fairly extensive and exhaustive review process.

Section 14J then says that, once a minister has made such a declaration, he or she can make it available to the public in any way he or she thinks fit. In other words, the section provides a way for the minister to announce publicly the withdrawal of funds from an organisation which has failed to meet the standards as set out in the act.

Clause 4 of this bill says that where the minister makes such a public statement under 14J, that statement will not become the subject of a defamation action. Similarly, anyone who fairly reports or summarises the statement will not be liable to such an action.

I really fail to see the point of the inclusion of this provision in the Disability Services Act. I understand that Senator Tambling will be going ahead and describing this in much more detail later. It seems to me that this inclusion would be largely unnecessary because statements made by the minister under section 14J are already privileged under common law. Beyond that, why should the minister be protected from defamation actions if he or she goes further than a straightforward statement of the facts and actually does defame an organisation. For example, an organisation could have gone through the review process, be found to have breached certain standards, the panel may have recommended its funding be terminated and the minister may have agreed with that recommendation.

But let us say that, in the course of making his or her statement under section 14J, the minister includes details of the alleged physical abuse of the organisation's clients by several staff members. These allegations may be new, may not have been raised with the review panel and may have been rejected by the organisation. Surely that organisation and the individual staff members concerned have the right to take action against the minister for defamation.

Obviously, this sort of situation will not arise very often. Ministers are usually very careful about the sorts of public statements they make in such circumstances. But, even if we are talking about a very rare occurrence, I cannot see a valid reason for completely closing off this avenue of action and for giving the minister any additional legal immunity other than that already provided by common law.

I have to ask: what exactly is the government trying to do here? It seems as if it is trying to close the door very firmly on any recourse to legal action a disgruntled organisation may have once the minister has decided to cut off funding. It is really trying to leave absolutely no avenue to such an organisation. Although I do have some sympathy with that desire—especially in this area where a few organisations have been fighting tooth and nail against coming into line and fulfilling their requirements; indeed, some seem determined not to conform with the Disability Services Act—I really do not believe that this measure is necessary or fair.

I also make the point that, once again, the minister responsible for this amendment, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, is introducing yet another idea with absolutely no consultation with the organisations most likely to be affected. It is little wonder that these organisations, once they found out about this amendment—because they had no prior warning—were very highly suspicious of the government's motives. Accordingly, the Democrats will join the coalition in opposing clause 4. We do not have any other concerns about this bill.

I turn now briefly to the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill 1993, which also fits in with part 8 of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). Part 8 of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) contains a series of amendments which are designed to facilitate the introduction of complementary state and federal legislation in the regulation of therapeutic goods. Essentially, the Commonwealth government wants to set up a uniform national system of control over the quality and safety of therapeutic goods. These amendments will come into force once complementary legislation is in place in the various states.

That seems to us to be a sensible path to take, although, as Senator Richardson knows, an agreement on uniform national legislation and the actual appearance of complementary state legislation are two vastly different things. We had yet another demonstration of this only recently in the area of uniform information on tobacco products. The Commonwealth achieved the agreement of the states on national legislation only to find that Victoria backed out on the deal; it changed its mind and, at the last minute, moved away from tougher warnings on cigarette packets. Senator Richardson should not be counting his chickens before they have hatched when it comes to uniform therapeutic goods legislation. But, in spite of that proviso, the Democrats support the concept and amendments in part 8 of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993.

The Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill 1993 follows up on these amendments by giving the Commonwealth the power to collect charges in relation to registrations, listings and licences of therapeutic goods where those activities are carried out on behalf of the state pursuant to its complementary therapeutic goods legislation. As with the part 8 amendments, these changes are subject to the establishment of complementary state and territory legislation. I note that the government is anticipating the first complementary state and territory legislation early next year. In conclusion, all I can say is that I wish the minister the best of luck.

—I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Foreign Affairs. What truth is there in reports this morning that the government's $130 million, four-year population initiative for developing countries announced in the budget has been suspended on the basis of pressure from Senator Harradine? Does the government no longer agree with this objective, announced by Minister Bilney on 7 September, to significantly increase aid expenditure on population? Does the government also no longer agree with Mr Bilney that the proposed expenditure would help cut infant and maternal mortality in developing countries, give women greater control of fertility and reduce unsustainable population growth?

—The story in this morning's Canberra Times and some of the subsequent comment in other media have been based on incomplete information and totally exaggerate the significance of what has occurred in discussions to date on this issue.

PARA.TAB: The government did, of course, announce in the budget context a substantial increase in population related activities to a total of $30 million in 1993-94 and $130 million over the four years to 1996-97. This was in order to make a substantial move toward the OECD's Development Assistance Committee target of four per cent of assistance being devoted to population activities by the year 2000.

The vast majority of funds out of those allocated for 1993-94, and also those allocated for the whole four-year period, have already been committed either in terms of firm financial commitments or firmly communicated political commitments which it would not be appropriate for any government to break. Those commitments will all be honoured.

As to Senator Harradine's position—he can, of course, speak for himself—honourable senators will know that he has been long concerned, as he has made clear in estimates committee hearings and elsewhere, about a number of the aspects of the government's population program. For example, one of his key concerns has been the possibility of people being coerced in family planning programs. That concern is very much shared by the government and AIDAB, our aid agency.

The principle of voluntarism is central to all of our population activities. We have been making some important strides in getting that principle accepted, especially in China, where there have long been question marks raised about the nature of some of the programs in question.

A more fundamental concern of Senator Harradine—it was triggered again this year by the scale of the funding increase in the budget—is one that goes to what might be described as the basic intellectual foundations of the government's population policy, that is to say the relationship that exists between rapid population growth on the one hand and continued impoverishment, environmental degradation and other matters of developmental concern on the other.

In the course of discussing this issue with Senator Harradine recently, we proposed that an appropriate development economist—someone with an international reputation who is fully independent and has no axe to grind on these matters in issue—be asked to spend a few months reviewing the available evidence as to the nature of the relationship between the variables I have mentioned and reporting to the government on that issue. We agreed that we would receive and consider that report before we made any commitment as to the expenditure of the remaining—that is to say, quite small—part of the population budget, which is that part in respect of which neither financial nor political commitments have already been made.
We believe in policy making in development assistance matters, as elsewhere, being conducted rationally and on the basis of the best available evidence.

PARA.TAB: Since 1989, purchasing policy at the federal level and the procedures associated with it have undergone significant reform and, in the main, those reforms have received bipartisan support. TALK.START.PARA: —What has Nick Bolkus been doing?

—This is showing him up!

—Those three initiatives being taken together give us a good chance of building on the basis of the good work that has been done in the past, including that by my colleague Senator Bolkus who is being so gratuitously attacked from the back benches over there. He is happily on the front bench over here and Senator Kemp is happily on the back bench over there. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. My question is about Minister Crean's clean green food. The minister will recall that, in his answer to my question on notice about DDT on 1 September, he said that DDT usage had been prohibited since 1987. The minister should also be aware of the warnings given by Professor Ben Selinger, the chair of the National Registration Authority, regarding the alarming potential for DDT contamination of Australian beef. What action did the minister take to pay regard to these warnings? What action will the minister take in future to prevent a recurrence of the contamination of beef? Will the minister acknowledge that, regardless of the level of current usage, the effect of residual organochlorines is to directly affect the potential of Minister Crean's admirable push for clean green exports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt Senator Bell's question is prompted by the reports in the last day or so concerning DDT residues in cattle in Queensland. On that subject and the related more general matters to which he refers, I am advised as follows. In the Queensland case, the original violative carcass was from a mob of 46 animals sold last month at auction and sourced from a single property. Three Queensland export meat establishments purchased stock from that auction and have been required to trace and retain suspect product for further testing. Testing has indicated that meat from other animals in the mob contained residues of DDT.

PARA.TAB: A small amount of meat suspected of having DDT residues may have been distributed for domestic consumption prior to regulatory action to retain and test all suspect product, but given the safety margins in establishing maximum residue level in foods, the risk to any consumer who may have consumed suspect meat is assessed as negligible. The property which produced the suspect animals has been quarantined and all appropriate measures taken to trace the suspect beef.

As to the more general policy reaction of the government to these concerns which Senator Bell has been expressing for some time, we have had an integrated action plan in place for the control of organochlorine residues in beef for the past five years. Under this plan, more than 800,000 cattle have been tested and the organochlorine residue risk status of 130,000 properties has been determined. This plan has ensured that Australia's organochlorine residue violation rate has remained below 0.1 per cent for the past three years. Control measures for at risk properties continue to be administered by the states and territories, rather than the Commonwealth.

This particular incident and the concerns that have been triggered by it should not be any cause for concern for overseas or domestic consumers. Systems are in place to minimise the risk of contaminated product entering the food chain. The adequacy of these programs remains under very close scrutiny by federal and state governments. The fact that contaminated product was detected, I guess, from another point of view, serves to demonstrate that adequate measures for consumer protection are in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't you read it?
—If honourable senators are interested, I am perfectly happy to read it but I am running out of time. I seek leave to incorporate the rest of the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: At the August 1993 meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Resource Management it was agreed that the use of heptachlor to treat funnel ants in sugar cane would be phased out by December 1994.

Land previously treated with heptachlor will continue to be used for sugar cane production but livestock grazing is not permitted on treated land or land adjacent to sugar can growing areas where the possibility of contamination may also exist.

This is a matter that is being addressed by the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency. I understand that an investigation was carried out by the NSW Government on action that might be taken to clean up these sites so as to minimise possible contamination of livestock and to ensure they do not adversely affect urban dwellings. I will seek additional detail on this issue from the Minister for the Environment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DSTO Food Science Branch, Scottsdale, Tasmania

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel inform the Senate as to whether a decision has been made regarding the future of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation's food science branch in Scottsdale, Tasmania? What effect will such a decision have on the local economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —The food science branch of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, currently located at Scottsdale in northern Tasmania, has been reviewed under Defence's commercial support program. The CSP review examined the two main functions of the branch—namely, research and development of food science and technology, and specialised food production for the Australian Defence Force.

PARA.TAB: After a thorough process of evaluation I am pleased to announce that the Chief Defence Scientist has decided to adopt the in-house proposals for both functions ahead of a range of external bids. These in-house proposals put together by the staff at Scottsdale were assessed to be superior against the technical criteria and also offered significant cost advantages. I emphasise that these were objective advantages that the current work force was able to demonstrate over the bids from commercial bodies already working in the food science and production fields.

This review will result in a substantial restructuring of the current operation at Scottsdale, leading to an overall cost saving of 17 per cent over the status quo. Staff numbers will be reduced by 25 per cent. The new operational arrangements that will be put in place by the in-house teams are expected to result in an improved level of service to Scottsdale's Defence Force clients.

With the CSP review complete, the Defence Science and Technology Organisation will plan on retaining the food science branch at Scottsdale for at least the medium term. The decision emphasises the true worth of the commercial support program in the defence organisation where open commercial competition can produce superior service to the Defence Force whilst making considerable financial savings.

The decision will have significant positive benefits for northern Tasmania in both economic terms and in terms of the social fabric of the area. I am sure the population of Scottsdale is relieved that this period of uncertainty about the future of the facility is over. I also believe that it will be particularly pleased with the result in this case. I congratulate the staff of the food science branch at Scottsdale for putting together this superior and successful bid.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It is it true that Australia is seeking to sell uranium to Taiwan through a third country? If yes, is that country the United States? Would the sale of uranium to Taiwan contravene the conditions normally applied by Australia to its uranium sales if the sale were made directly to Taiwan? Is the government seeking a circuitous route for these uranium sales, so as to circumvent the conditions which it maintains to the Australian public guarantee the safety of these sales and does it indicate a higher priority being given to commercial profit than to matters of longer term safety?

—The government is aware of the potential for trade with Taiwan in this area as, indeed, with many others. In line with our interest in exploring all avenues for increasing our bilateral trade, we are keeping under review the question of possible uranium sales to Taiwan.

PARA.TAB: The basic difficulty is that because of its unique international circumstances—which I guess I do not need to more fully describe now—Taiwan is unable to meet all the normal requirements of Australia's uranium export policy. There are three conditions. Firstly, a customer party must be a party to the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty, the NPT: Taiwan, in fact, is a signatory. Secondly, it has to have accepted NPT full scope safeguards administered by the International Atomic Energy Agency. Taiwan has not satisfied that condition. Thirdly, the party in question must have concluded a bilateral government to government nuclear safeguards agreement with Australia which, again, for technical reasons I have described, Taiwan cannot and has not.

Canada has reached an agreement with the United States on the application of safeguards to Canadian uranium exports to Taiwan. The Canadian uranium would be processed in the US and re-exported to Taiwan under the coverage of American nuclear safeguards agreements with Taiwan. Officials have discussed with the US the Canada-US-Taiwan supply agreement, and American policy and practice on the conclusion of similar agreements. These discussions imply, however, no commitment that Australia would eventually conclude an agreement similar to Canada's.

The key issue is whether and on what basis any sales of Australian uranium to Taiwan would be able to satisfy Australia's stringent nuclear safeguards necessary to ensure that uranium was used only for peaceful purposes. The government's overriding concern will be to satisfy ourselves that any arrangements entered into would provide a fully satisfactory safeguards regime consistent with current policy and would thus enhance important nuclear non-proliferation objectives. If there were any doubts on that point, there would be no possibility of uranium sales to Taiwan proceeding.
