As the Minister for Justice has recently announced, it is being addressed in a comprehensive way. He has recently released three discussion papers containing proposals for further major reform of the bankruptcy law. That reform will build on the reforms the government made to the law last year. The proposals are aimed in particular at further improving and modernising the ability of bankruptcy trustees to obtain, for the benefit of creditors, money and property that a bankrupt may have sought to transfer to others in anticipation of bankruptcy. Secondly, we are looking at reforming the provisions relating to arrangements with creditors short of bankruptcy by streamlining them and dealing with areas open to abuse. Thirdly, we are looking at streamlining the administration of bankruptcy—for example, by providing a one-stop service for voluntary bankruptcy. TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Cook was asked by Senator Brownhill about the inclusion of rice in Australian submissions on impediments to the Japanese market. With Senator Brownhill's very gracious consent, I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday Senator Brownhill asked my colleague, the Minister for Trade a question concerning the inclusion of rice in Australian submissions on impediments to the Japanese market.
I note that the honourable Senator drew on a recent edition of my department's publication, "Asialine" as the source of his question.
"Asialine" is widely distributed through the Australian business community to generate greater public interest on trade issues with Asia.
The particular "Asialine" article reports on two Australian submissions to Japanese Government advisory bodies seeking changes to importing practices in Japan.
One of these—the submission to the Import Board sets out impediments to Australia's exports of agricultural products.

It was formally submitted to the Import Board by the Australia-New Zealand Chamber of Commerce in Japan but was prepared in close cooperation with our Embassy in Tokyo, drawing on advice from Australian exporters.
The Import Board submission contains a section on impediments in the grains trade, and specifically rice.

PARA.TAB: The submission notes that "Australia is continuing to press for the abolition of quantitative restrictions (on grain imports) in the Uruguay Round negotiations".

ANSWER.PARA: The submission to the Office of the Trade Ombudsman (OTO) addresses standards and certification issues limiting the trade in Australian products.
In preparing this submission my department received input from a wide range of government and industry sources.

Since the difficulties confronting Australian rice exporters in the Japanese market are not based on Japanese standards or certification arrangements but rather on the provisions of Japan's Staple Food Law Australia's OTO submission did not include rice.
The government expects that the issues raised in both submissions will be addressed constructively by the Japanese advisory bodies and in ongoing consultations.
Indeed the "Asialine" article anticipates future submissions and invites Australian exporters to provide details of constraints on their trade for possible inclusion.

Australian ministers who are attending the Australia Japan Ministerial Committee meeting in Tokyo on 2 November will have an opportunity to raise rice import issues and other matters raised in the Import Board and OTO submissions with their Japanese counterparts.
You can be assured that the Australian Government is working closely with the Australian rice industry in seeking to break into the Japanese market.
With the backing of the industry, the government has insisted on the necessity of a Uruguay Round outcome involving comprehensive tariffication without exception including for Japan's rice sector.

In addressing the current shortfall in Japan, the government has pressed the Japanese government for equitable treatment for Australian suppliers and has joined with Australian industry representatives in meeting Japan's Food Agency to discuss Australia's supply capability.
In seeking to develop demand for imported rice, the government has worked closely with the Australian rice industry on its participation in trade promotion events in Japan.

That is the Prime Minister of this country.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that I am concerned about, too, is this question about the admittance for elective surgery. The Prime Minister said on 25 February:

SPEECH.PARA: We've got half a percentage problem in hospital admittance for elective surgery, therefore we should wreck Medicare and put in basically a private health insurance system. I mean, it would be an absurdity.
That is the Prime Minister's colourful language.

PARA.TAB: On another occasion a few days earlier he said that only about 2.5 per cent of patients were on the waiting lists. The current Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) has revised those estimates of the Prime Minister. The minister for health at the time, Mr Brian Howe, said:

SPEECH.PARA: While the average waiting time for elective surgery in this country is one month, there are some people waiting longer for particular types of surgery, such as hip replacements . . .
But he was going around talking about this one-month nonsense.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howe talked about extra funding to help with the waiting lists. He said that this extra funding would help shorten waiting lists. Of course, what he did not tell the Australian people—and we have been told since by the new minister—is that there is no real way of measuring the waiting lists. He said that the states did not actually collect those figures and others calculate them in different ways.

The then minister for health emphasised strongly that there was no crisis in the health care system and that these waiting lists of 100,000 people were really just playing with figures, effectively, and that it was all some awful political plot against the government. Of course, the reality is that in came a new Minister for Health and he acknowledged that this was, in fact, a serious matter that needed addressing. But the Prime Minister and his Minister for Health in the months leading up to the election tried to convince the Australian people otherwise.

Let us also just have a quick look at the ALP health policy that the government took to the election. The government said that it was going to pay $25 million per year for four years to contract with private hospitals for elective surgery. That has not been done.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is being done.
—No, it is not being done. The government has done some creative accounting. Perhaps Senator Richardson has not realised or perhaps it was on his instruction; I do not know which.
—The tenders will be let in the next couple of months.
—Senator Richardson should go back and look at his calculations. Is that new funding? No, it is not.
—Yes, the whole $25 million—the lot. You are just wrong.

—The minister is using old money. I will just take it that he does not understand the figures and be kind to him. The government said it would retain the national health strategy. Within a short time after being re-elected, the government abolished that. That got chucked out the window. In relation to the review team, the government's policy said, `It is vital we have an ongoing review and reform strategy to meet the health needs of all Australians'. The new minister chucked that out of the window very fast.

PARA.TAB: The government said it would need to have a Commonwealth dental health program. That, of course, has been delayed. And the government's national waiting list program, which, of course, relates to the elective surgery, is involved in the creative accounting figures that I mentioned earlier. I will come to those later and spell them out for the minister. I do not have enough time to dwell on it now. I might have to give him a private briefing.

The reality, of course, is that this minister, to give him his due, has come in and said that he does not have any ideological baggage—which is a shorthand way of saying he does not believe in anything—and he has flagged a number of changes in the health care system, although we were told prior to the election by the Prime Minister and the former Minister for Health that it was all going fine, that everybody had access, that it was great, that funding was fine and that there were no problems.

But, of course, a few things have happened since the election that are worth putting on the record. In the March to June quarter—in other words, the first quarter since the election; and this is the only figure we have so far—57,000 people have dropped out of private health insurance. I know the minister will be concerned about that. I expect that by the time we get to the end of this first six months we will have at least 100,000 people who have dropped out of private health insurance. So what will that do to the burden on the public sector?

Only four months after the election and the minister was flirting with gap insurance. He said on the John Laws program in July that he was looking at ways `to get some certainty into the amount that you are likely to get charged when you go into hospital, and some way of the funds being able to insure for the whole of the cost'. That was pretty quick after everybody saying that everything was okay.

Labor abolished the ability to insure for the gap, of course. That was in place prior to the Labor government coming into power in 1983 and Labor chucked it out the window, so Australians are no longer able to insure for the gap. Now, after the election is safely over, the minister is saying that he wants do something about that.

He also says that he wants to introduce an extra levy on those earning over $60,000. He is talking about raising the levy to 2.5 per cent. That is interesting because on a Channel 9 program on 2 May he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have no plans whatsoever to try and jack it up. I mean, it's fairly high . . . I think there are other ways to contain the costs and pay for them than simply jacking up the levy.
He also said:
I have indicated there are no plans whatsoever for either the reintroduction of a co-payment or a rise in Medicare levy and I stand by that.
This is 27 May now. He said:
I have no plans to recommend them whatsoever.
We are now having these floated as the minister goes around the country. The minister also said just the other day:

The trouble is . . . when people on higher incomes drop out of private insurance, they do elbow the old pensioner out of the queue because if you're on a hundred grand a year you know how to work systems.
Of course, we know that. We have people like the Prime Minister, who is on over $200,000 a year and has five dependents, who is working the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just given him a pay increase.

—His pay is $202,990, if Senator Richardson is aspiring to the job. That is his prime ministerial salary, his back bench salary and all of his allowances. The minister has already acknowledged that there is pretty widespread disgust about the Prime Minister's health insurance position because he is having his health bills paid by the battlers' taxes. I think that is pretty clear. Senator Richardson has almost given us chapter and verse about what he is going to do about that, but there was no mention about that from the Labor Party before the election.

PARA.TAB: The minister has also made some pretty unrealistic claims about what sort of money he is going to get from policing overservicing and fraud. During the election campaign the government said that it would help fund its health budget by getting at least $400 million during a crackdown on fraud and overservicing. Now it is saying it will get $25 million this year and $65 million next year, but in the estimates committee hearing the secretary to the department acknowledged that that was pretty much a guesstimate.

Another thing the minister has done is try to wipe out Medicare for eye tests. The nation revolted against that and the eye tests for families and elderly people were saved, but honourable senators will remember that in the budget they were going to be slugged $49.50 for a first consultation with an optometrist and $25 for a follow-up consultation. Medicare was starting to unravel pretty smartly after the election.

We have had an acknowledgment that the private hospitals are not going to be conned into the government's plan to contract private beds, yet leading up to the election we were told that this was going to be the great salvation and this was how we were going to deal with the waiting lists. The minister has now admitted that the waiting lists are a priority issue to be tackled, despite the Prime Minister's approach, yet he acknowledged back in early May that he would be worried if the percentage of private health insurers got any lower. We know very directly that waiting lists and private health insurance are intimately connected. The minister has made that connection himself on a number of occasions. The minister has said that without private insurance the public system would collapse very rapidly.

Early in Senator Richardson's term as Minister for Health a national health summit was called by the states to produce a new and workable national health policy. The leadership had passed to the states at that stage because the federal government had had its head in the sand for so long.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come off it!

—The minister acknowledges that; he had to go along with his hands out as just another member of that summit. If Senator Richardson is to take a leadership role now to reform and save Medicare, we will be glad. But it is an indication of how dishonest the minister's government was prior to the election that these changes are now being endorsed by him. Even if he is right after the event, it has been a very sad lesson for the Australian people. We told them at the time of the failures of Medicare, which the government denied so strenuously, and its advertising campaign put a false impression across to Australians about how well Medicare and the public health system was going, and now the government is finally acknowledging the truth of all that we said prior to the election.

PARA.TAB: Do honourable senators remember former Minister Brian Howe's co-payment being gutted by his own party as the price of the Prime Minister's bid for leadership?

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask Senator Crowley.

—Senator Crowley was one of the leaders of this. It is her main claim to fame. She has a place on the front bench as a result of that, but she has a lot to answer for. The health system in Australia is the poorer for the price of Prime Minister Keating's leadership bid and the support he got from members like Senator Crowley.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howe has said that there would need to be a lift in the Medicare levy from 1.25 per cent to 1.53 per cent and further increases in the levy would be needed in later years if there were no co-payment. Of course, we know now that that is one of the awful realities which is facing this new minister. What will he do about the Medicare levy for the rest of us? He has already flagged that he will put it up for those earning more than $60,000.

In July, on radio, he flirted publicly with the idea of an employer health care levy; he would not rule it out. Obviously, it is attractive to the Labor party. It can be sold as part of the social wage—get the ACTU's support, and Bob's your uncle. The government has done that with the training levy and the superannuation guarantee levy. It is not beyond the imagination that that is how such a proposal would be sold by this government. Of course, the price in jobs lost and the burden of on-costs to businesses in Australia would be enormous, but I would not be at all surprised if the minister is quite seriously considering that route.

These are the changes to Medicare that will be needed in some form or another if it is to be saved. Senator Richardson has these dilemmas on his plate right now. He is constrained by his caucus, we all know that, and that is why he has ruled out any tax incentives for private health insurance. He is a bit like a rat in a trap going round and round, trying to find measures that are ideologically satisfactory to his colleagues and yet which deal with the reality he knows he is facing in saving the public health system.

Even Medibank Private did not help too much because only four months after the election—it is government owned, as honourable senators will recall—it hiked its premiums up an average of $100 a week, putting even more people onto the public health system.

TALK.START.PARA: —One hundred dollars a week; that is pretty heavy.

—Sorry, a year. That cannot have helped the minister, but it is an indication of the problems that face the government in trying to save the public system when people, for one reason or another, are voting with their feet out of private health insurance.

PARA.TAB: The minister has rightly acknowledged that private health insurance must be encouraged; he has rightly acknowledged that problems in dealing with the gap and with certainty in hospital bills have to be solved. What he is failing to acknowledge publicly, although there is a bit of coat dragging now over the Medicare levy increase for the rich, is that there have to be more resources put into health care. One way is to encourage people not to be totally dependent on the public sector.

Of course, we in the opposition have long supported the right of people to have a choice. To that end, we wanted to encourage people through tax incentives, whether they are low or middle income earners, to get into private health insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —A rebate would be even better.

—Yes, a rebate would be even better, as Senator O'Chee says. There is much more that I could say on this, but I know we are limited for time and I have colleagues who want to have their share of the debate.

PARA.TAB: I do question the expenditure of $7 million on studies as to why public hospital lists are so long. One of the basic reasons, as the minister well knows, is that not enough people can afford now to go to the private sector. More and more people who are fit or well to do and who could well insure themselves—the young, single people, for example, with only themselves to support—are opting to take their chance and join the queues when they need hospitalisation.

The minister could save some of his $7 million by trying to put in incentives to help people get into private health insurance. He could try giving people a choice and helping them to determine their own health care arrangements, not just by slogging the rich because that will produce a very disjointed health system. He needs to help those middle to low income people if he has any concern at all about social justice.

There is an urgent need for reform of the health care system. The public resources cannot cope and only by adopting our policy can there be any hope for the public system. Effectively, the minister's statements have acknowledged that. It is a crying shame that the pre-election rhetoric and the dishonest advertising campaign of the Labor Party meant that the Australian people were not allowed to know the truth about the health system in Australia. The coalition proposed retention and improvement of Medicare. It is urgently needed. In conclusion, I quote from our policy:

SPEECH.PARA: .Medicare will be retained and significantly improved. It will remain a system of universal health cover.

.We will restore the balance between the public and private sectors by encouraging individuals to provide for their own health care by taking out private health insurance. A series of financial subsidies will be offered which will be heavily weighted to those on low incomes and the aged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been said by Senator Newman about that which happened in the last election. I am glad she did because I had intended to traverse some of that ground myself. There is no doubt that Medicare was a significant issue in the last election, as well it should have been. There is also no doubt that once again it got a ringing endorsement from Australia. The opposition's policies, if that is what one could call them, were once again rejected.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman began her contribution by saying that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had said in the election campaign that Medicare is working. Well, thank God he did. Medicare was working then; it is now. It represents a great public hospital system, arguably the best in the world. If there are better ones I would like to know about them. But as with any system in the world, we would be crazy if we did not keep looking at it in order to work out ways to improve and protect it. Anything that I do will not now, or ever, drag Medicare down; it will simply improve it. That is all I could ever seek to do.
When Mr Howe promised extra funding to help waiting lists, he delivered on that promise. I cannot understand this `old money, new money' silly argument that Senator Newman has been going on about..

TALK.START.PARA: —It is money you had already committed.
—No, it is not. There was a promise in the election campaign of $100 million of new money. That promise will be kept.
—When?

—If Senator O'Chee listens, he will find out. I am here to enlighten him. If only he would open his ears as well as his mouth he might hear. When we complete these negotiations with the private hospitals, we will have some tenders. I intend to go to cabinet with a proposal for those tenders towards the end of November. It is possible that it may be the first Tuesday in December. It will just depend on the timetable of cabinet business.

PARA.TAB: I have had lengthy discussions with the Catholic hospitals in particular. They put some proposals to me and we have talked about those proposals. I have suggested some changes and they have gone back to consider them with their own people. We will be calling tenders to see how much interest there is, but certainly the Catholic hospitals are expressing some interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many beds will you get?

—In terms of how much interest there may be, I do not know yet. No-one can know until we call for tenders and see what reaction we get. That having been said, because I am determined to make sure that $25 million over four years gets spent helping to reduce waiting lists, I will not simply pocket the money or send it back for something else if not all of it is taken up by that route. What we will do is fund some real attempts in the public hospital system to reduce those waiting lists.

PARA.TAB: Much of this discussion is about waiting lists and I think we should start to put it in perspective. Even if we accepted the extraordinary figures that the opposition used during the election campaign, and in particular Dr Bob Woods—if anyone can remember him; he was the one who was slaughtered in Lowe—one would have to accept that today 97 per cent of Australians who turn up at the doors of a public hospital in Australia get treated promptly, get treated well and are satisfied. There can be some delays with some three per cent of Australians.

When we talk about waiting lists and efforts to try to reduce them, the first point to make is that there must be waiting lists. There ought to be waiting lists. Senator Herron as a surgeon would know that one does not treat everybody tomorrow afternoon. Every surgeon and every specialist wants to know what he or she is doing in the months ahead and will plan a schedule. That is quite normal. Every hospital in the country, public or private, has to know what is going to happen in its operating theatres in three months time or six months time. They will always need to know that.

I am comfortable with the idea of waiting lists. What I am not comfortable with, of course, is that some people are waiting too long. That is why just one of the measures that I have proposed, to try to reduce the pressures on those waiting lists and to try to make sure that those who are in some sort of pain and discomfort do not have to wait too long, is first off to do something about private health insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spend $7 million on a study.

—It has nothing to do with studies. I have acknowledged that the great success of Medicare through the 1980s and into the 1990s has meant that more and more people have felt so comfortable with and had such confidence in the system that they have dropped out of private health insurance and been content to rely on Medicare.
—Have you heard of the recession? They couldn't afford the premiums.

—Senator Herron has to understand that the drop-out in private health insurance occurred even when the economy was on the up. When we had a boom from 1987 to 1989 people were dropping out. They dropped out because they believed in Medicare, as well they should. They knew there was a good enough system underpinning them. But I digress, Mr Deputy President.

PARA.TAB: I accept that one of the ways we will have to explore in making sure that some of the pressure is taken off waiting lists is at least to put a floor under private health insurance and try to get the numbers back up. In looking at that, I have come up with some ideas which I will pursue with my cabinet and caucus colleagues during November and December. We will then make sure that is made public and lies on the table until legislation is introduced next year.

In terms of that I am certainly looking at a higher levy for higher income earners. I have not settled on $60,000 or 2 1/2 per cent, as Senator Newman claims. In fact, I have not yet received from the department all of the modelling on this to see what kind of effect at different income levels an increase will have.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't have any effect. I'll tell you about that shortly.

—Even the AMA thinks it will have an effect. This is a great day for me. Senator Herron has finally disagreed with the AMA. I am delighted. I hope he can make more of a habit of it. The AMA and also the private health industry association agree with me. While I do not believe that any move of this kind will turn around the problem in a huge way, it will have its effect when combined with a number of other measures. Those measures include having a look at a form of gap insurance—not a gap insurance that resembles in any way the stupid proposals put forward by the opposition in the last election.

PARA.TAB: In looking at health costs in Australia, it is important to note that we have hovered between eight and 8 1/2 per cent of GDP for some years. That is a very, very healthy figure for Australia to be at. It is higher than the figure in the UK, but it is nowhere near the US where it is currently 14 per cent. Only a few weeks ago papers released by the Democrat administration announcing its reforms suggested that the figure may blow out to some 20 per cent during the next decade. Those massive blow-outs must not occur here. In a country like Australia we have other things to spend our money on. If we are going to develop as a nation in the way that we need to, we have to make sure that we have some kind of hold on health costs.

The only way that I would consider recommending gap insurance to the party of which I am a member would be to make sure that it also effectively capped doctors' fees. That would mean that funds will have to contract with private hospitals and doctors to determine the fees in advance of the procedures being carried out. If they can keep doctors to whatever gap is allowed, then those funds will stay in business.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't make any difference.

—That will make one hell of a difference. What Senator Herron has to understand—and there are many things he does not—is that, even according to the private health industry, up to 40 per cent of those who drop out claim the reason they did is that they get hit by huge bills by some of his mates when they go to hospital. They think they are covered for the lot but they do not get it because Senator Herron and his mates charge too much. I should not say that, because there are those who tell me that Senator Herron is a very fair man—I would not ever want to accuse him of not being fair—but, certainly, there are too many who charge too much. At some point Australia must address that issue. I know that those opposite have a vested interest in never addressing it, but we on this side of the house do not have that vested interest and we will never let it guide us or rule us. We just will not. We will not accept anything like an uncapped, unlimited gap insurance that will just blow health costs right out of the window. We never will.

PARA.TAB: When one looks at this opposition to Medicare from Senator Newman and the rest of those opposite who are so often inclined to go on with it, it is worth noting that not even their own colleagues will cop it anymore. I am glad to see that Senator O'Chee is in attendance. The National Party is changing its mind, and more power to it. I am really impressed.

I have a press release from Mr Garry Nehl, the honourable member for Cowper, a New South Wales seat. He is not a bad fellow, our Garry. He has shown us the way and shown us that the National Party can see this too. I will not read out the whole press release.

TALK.START.PARA: —You never would.
—Senator O'Chee no doubt has it. He can read it out.
—You always selectively quote.
—It is very hard to see how these will be selective quotes. Senator O'Chee should just listen to this:

SPEECH.PARA: Moving an amendment to get National Party endorsement of bulk-billing for low income earners, the Member for Cowper, Mr Garry Nehl, said it was obvious that the abolition of bulk-billing played a major part in the Coalition's loss at the last Federal election . . . Low income earners, who make-up the traditional base of the National Party, would have been hurt by this policy as well.

I do not know how Senator O'Chee can say that is out of context. This is a very short press release. At the end of the day what we are seeing is the National Party finally coming on board with Labor. I am delighted to see it. I think it is interesting that Mr Nehl says:
I have always argued strongly in the Joint Party Room as a member of the Coalition's Taskforce on Health for bulk-billing to be retained for low income earners.

However, in the past, I have not succeeded in having this made Coalition policy. This is unfair for those who are finding it hard to make ends meet . . . It is significant that my own party has now supported me in my fight, a fight which we will now be able to take to our Coalition partners in a much stronger fashion.

I assume that Senator O'Chee is not distancing himself from his colleague. I assume that he agrees with every word that his colleague has said. I must say that I find that a pretty compelling case indeed from Mr Garry Nehl. But I do not even have to rely on Mr Nehl. Even in the Liberal Party the cracks in the dyke are appearing, and Senator Newman and others are finding it very difficult to run around and plug them.

PARA.TAB: I now can quote no greater source than a person some people tout as a future leader—namely, Senator Bronwyn Bishop, who is now looking at going on to greater things in another place. I refer to something Senator Bishop said the other day at a press conference. She gives a lot of those. I do not know whether anyone has noticed lately, but, my God, the old Bronwyn gives a few press conferences. I cannot turn on a television without seeing one.

On this occasion my eyes lit up, my ears opened. There she was saying `bulkbilling is here to stay'. Senator Bishop has taken a long time to come on board, but there we are. When we get it from a source that important, when we get it from a source that high, when we get it from a source that influential, how can the Liberal Party walk away any longer? The National Party has walked away and now, from within the Liberal Party's own ranks, the contender has said `bulkbilling is here to stay'. I do not know what the hierarchical arrangement is in the Liberal Party. I try to work it out, but it is difficult—it is never easy. One wonders where Senator Bishop rates as against, say, Senator Newman. I reckon she must rate pretty highly.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want to answer my interjections, do you?

—Senator Newman does not want to hear what I am saying. I can understand why she wants to keep interjecting, but keep talking I will. When Senator Bronwyn Bishop speaks in that tone, in that vein, I think all of us should sit up and take notice. That is exactly what I have done. I would not want us to get carried away and listen to everything that she says. That would be a very big mistake indeed.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at Senator Bishop's statements about bulkbilling and the extraordinary incapacity of the opposition—save, now, the National Party and Senator Bishop—to understand what is at stake, one has to look at what occurred in the last election. In the last election the coalition put up a policy that was simply unsaleable to Australia, a policy that was roundly and soundly rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the terms of my motion, which do not relate to the opposition's statements prior to the election. They do relate, in fact, to the government's re-election rhetoric and highlight the need for urgent reform of the health care system. Would you mind asking the minister to stick to the motion.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Order! There is no point of order. The minister is entitled to range widely over the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is very wide—and wrong.

—I always quote exactly. Last night, when Senator MacGibbon made the great mistake of saying that I had not read Fightback!, I quoted the page and the chapter at him just to make sure he got the message. If Senator Newman needs that today, she can get it as well.

PARA.TAB: It must be remembered now that bulkbilling is going up every year—another two per cent this year—so that we now have 80 per cent of all services bulkbilled. The graph just keeps going up, mainly because the Australian people, and of course the profession, are now coming on board. We are introducing new legislation on overservicing, in complete cooperation with the AMA.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you worry about overservicing.
—I am worried, but I am doing something about it.
—You are not worried about overservicing.
—I know those opposite do not want me to talk about their policies on bulkbilling, but I am going to do it anyway.
—You are only interested in shouting me down.
—Senator Newman says `shouting me down'; I thought I was the one on my feet. I thought she was the one sitting down. I do not have to shout her down. She should be shutting up.

PARA.TAB: I return to the question of bulkbilling, which I am definitely going to get out. In the last election campaign, when those opposite sought to abolish it, they made some terrible mistakes. Firstly, they tried to reduce the Medicare rebate from 85 per cent to 75 per cent. What they did, of course, was create a tremendous disincentive for doctors to bulkbill. So great was that disincentive that there is no way they have even been bulkbilling for pensioners or for the unemployed. We were going to get to the stage where up-front out-of-pocket costs were the order of the day. If doctors chose to charge an up-front fee, low income earners, who currently pay nothing when they visit a GP—when they are ill they can go in and come out without paying anything—would have to find the AMA price of $32 before they could claim any rebates. If the rent is due, or the budget is tight, or a couple of the kids are sick, those kinds of up-front out-of-pocket costs simply cannot be met.

We pointed out this fact to Australians in the last election campaign, and this is what Australians accepted because they could see it there in black and white. They knew what those opposite were on about and they said no. Fortunately, because that policy is so disreputable and because it did so badly for them in the last election campaign, they have now been disowned by the National Party and by Senator Bishop.

I noticed that even in some of Senator Newman's comments she said, `I do not say the policy was wrong; it simply left us open to a fear campaign'. Does she say that means the opposition drops the policy? I would say `probably not, but who is to know at this stage'. That is a quote from Senator Newman on 10 April. That is exactly what she said. From 10 April to the end of October, Senator Newman has been unable to enlighten us any further because she still does not have a policy and she still has nothing to say.

When I look at the record, I see that being shadow health minister has not been a very flash job over the last decade—it has been a very hazardous job indeed; so many have hit the fence and so many have been defeated or resigned in disgrace. I really think there is still a hope for Senator Newman. There is still a chance. It may be the slimmest glimmer at the end of the tunnel, but it is still there. I suggest that Senator Newman try to grasp that tiny bit of light, and see whether she can march out into the fullness of real knowledge and integrity, and dump this rotten policy.

When it came to an analysis of the policy, those opposite finished up in so much strife that they could not sustain it. They have accused us of doing the wrong thing by the dental promise. We have promised $278 million over the next four years, and that is what we will spend. We promised $18 million in this financial year, and that is what we will spend. Negotiations with the states are going on right now. We have promised $55 million for palliative care over four years. We will spend every cent of that.

We have promised an additional $71 million to the hospital access program, which was provided for in last year's budget. We are spending that money and we will spend every single penny. Over the five years from 1993-98, we will spend $23 billion on the Medicare agreements with the states. We will spend $1.6 billion on pharmaceuticals this year. We will spend all of that money and maintain a great public system. But after a decade we will improve the public health system. We will make it so good that even the most rotten policy maker on the other side cannot tear it down. It will be immune from the worse attacks that those opposite can muster.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again with basically what is nothing more than a spot of Medicare bashing by the opposition. I must have listened to about half a dozen of these in all in the past three years. I believe that they provide little more than an opportunity for those opposite to sing the praises of the private health insurance industry. They really do not give up, and they certainly do not have the honesty to admit that they are running nothing more than a straight ideological campaign.

PARA.TAB: They have a specific agenda when it comes to Medicare that does not have any room whatsoever for talking about the positives that are in our Medicare system. They never seem to mention anything about the cost effectiveness of Medicare and the fact that it has kept down overall health costs. They never mention anything favourable about Medicare.

Opposition members never mention anything about the international comparisons that many people overseas make and the fact that they see our health care system as one of the most efficient and equitable in the world. I argue that the reasons those opposite never mention these things is because, basically, they want to destabilise and really destroy Medicare.

I am not saying for a moment that there are no problems with Medicare. I have spent the last eight months travelling around hospitals and community health centres talking to doctors. I have visited hospitals in rural South Australia as well as regional hospitals—very small hospitals. I have talked to those who run some of the largest hospitals in this country. Yes, there are specific problems, but very few, if any, of them can be solved by the way the opposition is proposing to deal with Medicare.

The coalition will not be happy until it has delivered the health care industry in this country into the groups that the coalition is so clearly representing—that is, basically, into the hands of the private health insurers and, to some extent, a few people in the medical specialty area. So I do not think there is a great deal of value to be had in listening to what the coalition is saying about health care in this country.

What disappoints me is that Medicare seems to be in grave danger of heading down the same track. I certainly want to talk to the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) about some of his suggestions. He should be very careful about who he is listening to and, in particular, about spending so much time with the private health insurance industry on the matter of financing our health care system.

TALK.START.PARA: —But I am going to reform them.

—Good luck. I appreciate the need to act quite promptly to solve some of the problems that Medicare is facing. I really do not understand why the minister apparently feels so compelled to bail out the private health insurance industry. We are constantly being told by this government that there is no room for inefficient industries in this country. We have had the level playing field—or the level killing field, whatever you like to call it—where industries are supposed to survive on their own merits, yet here we have an astonishingly inefficient industry which, as the minister has said, people are voting with their feet and their wallets to get out of. From some of his recent statements in the press, the minister seems to be suggesting that they need more customers. I have to ask him why.

PARA.TAB: If the issue is one of private insurance contribution to the Australian hospitals system, which is currently running at around $2 billion a year, why does the government not simply move to replace that contribution by raising the Medicare levy and making it much more progressive to ensure that higher income earners really pay their way? Increasing the Medicare levy by one per cent would more than cover the current contribution from private health insurance. Why is the minister not putting that suggestion in his papers that he puts before cabinet?

Why do we not move to fully fund our hospital and health system via the levy and let the private health insurance industry sink or swim on its own? I would like to hear from the minister as to why he is not putting up that idea as part of his health reform package. Everything else seems to be on the agenda. Why not that?

It is about time the government took on the private health insurers in the long-term interests of the Australian health system. I am concerned that the minister's proposals appear to signal his intention to do exactly the opposite. He has talked about gap insurance—indeed, he mentioned it again in this chamber today; he has talked about forcing higher income earners into private insurance; and he has talked about managed care systems, but he is apparently not prepared to talk about full public funding for Medicare.

I have absolutely no argument with the minister in terms of making the well-off pay more for their health care. But we should be doing it through Medicare rather than continuing to prop up an inefficient industry which is not crucial to the provision of basic—and I stress `basic'—health care services.

Let us just look at the industry itself. It carries on all the time about how people are leaving private health insurance as though it is some sort of great government conspiracy. The simple fact is that people are deciding not to take up private health insurance because they know it is not cost-effective for them. For example, for an average family of two adults and two children, the average cost of private health insurance has been calculated at $50,000 more than the value of the benefits received over the lifetime of the parents. That information comes from a Health Issues Centre research paper of September this year.

In other words, if one family put its health insurance premiums in the bank and used that money to pay for its health care costs as it required it, it would be $50,000 better off than the family that took out private health insurance. That is certainly efficient for the health insurance companies, but not for the paying customers.

There are other interesting facts about the private health insurance industry which hardly ever see the light of day in debates such as this. The minister has many more options that he acknowledges he should be considering. For example, the Commonwealth subsidises private funds to the tune of at least $500 million a year. This comes about because a significant proportion of public hospital beds are occupied by private patients and the full cost of the occupancy of a public bed is not recovered from the private insurers. This subsidy disadvantages the private hospitals.

Perhaps the minister could explain why he is not prepared to look at forcing private funds to pay the full cost of private patients in public hospitals. That would have a two-fold effect in that it would eliminate the disadvantage to the private hospitals and bring quite a bit of additional revenue into the public system. I have to ask him again why issues such as that are not on the table.

Private health insurance management costs are more than double the costs incurred by Medicare. If it were the other way around, I imagine that the coalition would be screaming from the rooftops about the inefficiencies of Medicare, but it seems to have overlooked that point.

How about getting the health insurance industry to introduce some efficiency measures into its administration before we start coercing people into taking out private health cover? The simple fact of the matter is tha private health insurance may be facing a crisis—although I note from the Sydney Morning Herald editorial of yesterday that its profits are far from unhealthy—but there is absolutely no reason for us to see the crisis as automatically translating into a general crisis in the Australian health system.

In addressing the problems we have, there are options for the minister other than continuing or increasing taxpayers' subsidies to the private health insurance industry. I suggest to the minister that going down that path is a very big mistake.

Public confidence in Medicare remains high, despite the best intentions of some to denigrate it. It is now time for the government to act on a lot of its pre-election rhetoric. We should see some action as a result of all those statements in support of Medicare that were made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

As we have been saying for some time, the Australian Democrats believe the best thing the government could do is to make Medicare the national insurer and, in relation to hospital care, extend Medicare to cover the choice of doctor and hospital in shared ward accommodation in either the private or public system.

We have also been saying for some time that the Commonwealth government should take over the direct funding of hospitals. I note that this suggestion was made only yesterday by the head of Victoria's Department of Health and Community Services, Dr John Paterson. I do not always agree with Dr Paterson, but on this issue in particular I believe he is entirely correct when he says it is time to clear the decks in health and welfare and sort out once and for all who does what between the Commonwealth and the states.

I would like to see the Commonwealth completely responsible for health care across the board but, as a starting point, it certainly makes good sense—economical sense, practical sense—for the Commonwealth to have at least direct control over hospital financing. The sooner that occurs the better. Perhaps that too is something the minister should have on the table as part of the reform package.

I am basically saying that I think the minister should take another look at the wisdom of continuing to subsidise the private health insurance industry. I think he should look at the long-term dangers of setting up a two-tier health care system where the rich have private insurance and the rest have Medicare. I think he should take another look at where his advice is coming from and at who will actually benefit from the reforms that he is suggesting. I do not believe the ultimate beneficiaries will be ordinary Australians who simply want access when they need it to quality health care. No, I think the ultimate beneficiaries will be the private health insurance companies and some doctors. If that happens, the minister will have written himself into history as the Labor minister who presided over the beginning of the end of Medicare.

In conclusion, I make some general comments about the problems as I see them and also the problems within this chamber when we come to debates such as this. Instead of getting down and looking at the issues, the underlying problems in our health system—for example, having a debate on the mental health care system and looking at some of the issues in the Burdekin report—we continually come back to this ideological battle: Medicare versus private insurance. I suggest that we should spend some time looking at the specific problems we are facing in hospitals.

Why do we have so many Australians, on the one hand, in our hospitals who should not be there and, on the other hand, people wanting to get into hospital who cannot? I have spent the last eight months visiting a wide range of hospitals. Basically the answer comes back to a lack of community support services. It comes back to the fact that in rural South Australia at 1 a.m. a `kind policeman' does not lock up a drunk and disorderly person; the policeman sends that person to hospital.

It comes back to the fact that, in places like rural South Australia—particularly on the west coast—mental health problems are largely ignored. There are virtually no community services; there is only one psychiatrist outside Adelaide. So what happens? The brunt of the problem is borne by the public hospital system. I could go on to give examples of specific hospitals where one can see elderly patients with dementia in a four-bed ward with three surgical patients; that is not uncommon. I would suggest that the minister at the table, Senator Schacht, also visit some of those small rural hospitals in South Australia.

In many cases it is the policies of this government that are actually undermining our hospital system in this way. These are the sorts of issues we should be debating and talking about. Why do we have to have 30 elderly residents before we can have a nursing home? Why do we have rural hospitals with whole wards shut—wards that could easily be converted into nursing home type accommodation? Government regulations and restrictions prohibit that from happening, so people have to share surgical wards in totally inappropriate accommodation options. It is certainly most distressing for nursing staff to have those sorts of difficulties facing them on a day-by-day basis.

I hope that next time we come to a health debate in this chamber we do not just get back to debating private versus public. Obviously, we have to talk about where the money is coming from. But let us look at some of the specific problems as to where money should be spent now. It is very inefficient to end up with people in hospital who should not be there. It is probably the most expensive option for someone suffering from dementia or for someone who has a drug dependency problem. We should be looking at a whole range of community services across this country to take pressure off our hospitals rather than continuing this never-ending debate of public versus private.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak on this important efficiency audit by the Australian National Audit Office in relation to the Department of Social Security's data-matching program. People will remember that when the tax file number was introduced the previous Treasurer, now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), promised Australia that it would never need to be extended for any purpose other than taxation. But he broke another promise by extending it to the social security system.

In the end, the Labor government secured the passage of this legislation by way of the not too subtle technique that it usually uses of a gun to the head of the coalition. The coalition was told that, if it opposed the bill, it would be branded as supporting people who deliberately fraud the social security system. When I suggested that we change a word, the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, wrote to Dr Hewson claiming that changing a single word in the bill would result in lost savings of up to $150 million a year.

As I said, the government claimed that the savings from this program would be $300 million a year. The auditor has concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: The downward variation in payments, which were the basis of the original estimates, represent only 17 million dollars of the 1992-93 savings.

The minister and his bureaucrats were claiming that their savings estimates were conservative. Now we find that a mere six per cent of these savings are being realised. We were told that $150 million would be down the tube if we changed one word.

But a closer examination of these latest claims shows that some $40 million of these savings are a direct result of the so-called deterrent factor and not directly related to data matching whatsoever; that is, when people found out that there was data matching involved or that the tax file number would be taken, they decided to declare their real income, to withdraw from applying for social security or whatever else they decided to do.

A further $13 million was attributable to identified overpayments which were also not included in the original savings estimates. In effect, this means that the department has changed the basis upon which it calculates its derived savings after the commencement of the program. Worst of all, it has quite deliberately tried to give the Australian parliament the false impression that the savings from this program are higher than they actually are. The Auditor-General's report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The DSS saving estimates available at June 1993 contained changes in methodology from the previous estimates, which should be clearly indicated. The ANAO considers that, when reporting to Parliament, the detailed basis on which DSS calculates estimates of savings from the program needs to be more transparent, with changes in methodology explained.

This matter is central to the concerns expressed by the non-government parties in 1990. At that time it was necessary for senators to make an informed decision as to whether the financial savings to be derived from data matching warranted the introduction of such an intrusive method of fraud control. In effect, we were asked to undertake a cost-benefit analysis that entailed an assessment not only of the financial costs and benefits but of the privacy repercussions as well.

PARA.TAB: It is disturbing to see that the department has not seen fit to undertake its own cost-benefit analysis of the program, despite the fact that analyses are a requirement of the program protocol that was passed with the data-matching legislation. The Auditor-General found in his report:

SPEECH.PARA: The full range of costs incurred by the data-matching program are substantially in excess of those previously quantified by DSS in their reports on progress.

It is estimated that the annual costs entailed in the data-matching program are about $14 million. This means that a program that entails matching the confidential financial and personal data of up to 11 million Australians on an ongoing basis is being legitimised on the basis of net savings that may be as low as $3 million per year. This is a long shot, and way out from the estimates trundled out by the government less than three years ago.

PARA.TAB: The auditor has suggested that the department conduct detailed cost-benefit analyses to assess the cost-effectiveness of the program more fully. It must be noted that the department has moved quickly to respond to this recommendation and included an analysis in its recently tabled report, which unfortunately I did not have the chance to speak on because I dashed down to the chamber to find that it had already gone through. However, it is quite telling that it had not seen fit to do so until it received this, what I would see as, not so gentle a reminder from the Auditor.

There can be no doubt that the data-matching program was and is technology driven. Three years ago a number of officers from the department went overseas to acquaint themselves with a new technology that would allow the automatic matching of millions of pieces of data in a relatively short period of time. The fact that this program is technology driven is recognised by the Auditor-General, who states in his report:

SPEECH.PARA: A key factor justifying the data-matching program was information technology developments which allowed millions of matches to be undertaken automatically resulting in the confirmation of voluntary compliance by clients in a great majority of cases.

However, the Auditor-General's report also reveals that the department has not been administering this technology driven program in the most efficient way possible. For example, it has been shown that a massive 85 per cent of the so-called matches that are identified through the data-matching process are not actually matches at all.

PARA.TAB: In some ways I wish Senator Powell were still here to have seen this Auditor-General's report. In fact, I feel inclined to post it to her. We sat through that committee hearing and we heard the officers from the department telling us that there would be 100 per cent accuracy. They told us that when we got a `hit', when it was a match, it would be definitely a positive hit and it would be somebody who was not giving the correct information or who was giving information to Social Security about their income that was not the same as the information in the Taxation Office.

We were told categorically that a match would be a match—that it would be a `hit' was the word they used. And what do we find? We find that 85 per cent of the reviews that are undertaken to resolve the data-matching results do not reveal an incorrect payment. They are wrong 85 per cent of the time. We match data on millions of people in Australia who are not defrauding the system. They get pulled out of the system, they get examined in much more detail and they have not done one single thing wrong. We were told categorically—Senator Richardson would remember; he was sitting there listening to it and he heard Mr Trevor Murphy say to us over and over again—`When we get a hit it will be right; we will be spot-on. Someone will be in receipt of an overpayment'.

Mr Murphy was wrong. Somehow the department now is examining 85 per cent of those matches which do not reveal an incorrect payment. But not only that; these 85 per cent represent some 64,000 clients whose financial and personal arrangements are subjected to departmental review without good reason.

The auditor has highlighted the fact that annual labour saving costs of $2.9 million would result if 46 cent or 30,000 of the unsuccessful matches could be eliminated. So we would have made savings if the department had got it right, if a hit was a hit, as it was called. But no, we find that 85 per cent of those people indicated as hits have not been in receipt of an overpayment. If we could correct 46 per cent of those, if we could eliminate those incorrect ones, then there would be approximately $2.9 million worth of savings.

The unnecessary, inappropriate and costly intrusion entailed in the data-matching program does not end here. Fortunately, the data-matching act does not allow the department to stop the continuation of a benefit as a result of data matching. Can you imagine all these people having their social security reduced or cut out because we had found these `hits', that were going to be so right as Mr Murphy said? Benefit does not stop, because they have to receive a section 11 letter; it has to be sent to the client first. This means that the review of the so-called match can be undertaken before a person's benefit is put in jeopardy. So we get these hits and the department then checks them. When the department has checked the match and believes that there has been an overpayment it sends out a section 11 letter.

Unfortunately, the auditor has found that a high proportion of section 11 letters are successfully disputed by clients. This means that the department is drawing inaccurate conclusions even after it has reviewed the so-called matches. So it does the matches, they come out of the computer, they are checked—these were the matches that were going to be 100 per cent right—and the department sends out section 11 letters, and still gets it wrong in 11 per cent of the cases. They have to provide evidence to the Department of Social Security.

We were told categorically that a match was a match and that it would be 100 per cent right. I can remember the officers sitting there telling us until they were blue in the face. I did not believe one word of it, and I was vindicated. I am going to go back through that Hansard. I can say `I told you so' on about three or four issues. Senator Richardson can remember that. I think Senator Richardson would have the good grace to agree that many of those things I raised have now come to fruition.

These are not the only data-matching related inefficiencies that have been highlighted by the auditor. He has recommended that the Department of Social Security distribute the costs incurred in data matching with the other government agencies that benefit from it. I am not sure but I think I also asked that question somewhere along the line. It is also recommended that greater emphasis be put on analysing the cost-effectiveness of each of the 70-odd projects that make up the data-matching program.

The auditor also concludes that variations between Department of Social Security officers are wider than necessary and recommends that it, and I quote because I do not like to use this word, `prioritise a reduction in the variability of the performance between offices, building upon the national quality assurance results'. Significantly, the auditor has concluded that up to $12 million in savings could be achieved by investigating clients whose benefits are either cancelled or voluntarily surrendered as a result of not providing their tax file numbers.

Finally, this audit report cannot be allowed to pass without making some comments about the extension of the use of the tax file number. I just said that the previous Treasurer, our now Prime Minister, promised us that the tax file number would not be extended. We were told that it was vital and necessary for this intrusive data-matching program that we should extend the tax file numbers. We were told that it was an integral part of the program. The distinct impression we were given was that, without the use of the tax file numbers, the data-matching program would be rendered largely unworkable. In stark contrast, the auditor has found that no identity frauds have been detected from data-matching projects like invalid or inconsistent tax file numbers that are used to identify personal identity data discrepancies.

In fact, the department now appears to be of the opinion that tax file numbers may not be necessary at all in the data-matching program. Other identifiers may be able to be used for the purposes of income matching and alternative strategies are being examined for handling personal identity discrepancies. We were told that we needed to extend the tax file number to make sure that we could catch people who were defrauding the social security system. We were told that the government would make $300 million of savings, and that was so far out that it is a joke. We were told that when a match was made, when data came across and was matched with the social security data, people plucked out of the computer would in fact be in receipt of an overpayment. The government was wrong, and it has been wrong on so many of these issues.

There we were, the `unrepresentative swill' as we are referred to by the former Treasurer and now Prime Minister, in that Senate committee, without the resources of the department, asking questions about protecting the privacy of millions of Australians. We asked pertinent questions about protecting many people who are not even involved in the social security system, such as people's spouses whose tax information is matched—millions of people who are involved in this data-matching process. With hindsight, those questions were absolutely spot-on. The department knew less about it than we appeared to know from examining the situation very closely.

I urge all senators, who have to make a decision within the next 24 hours or so as to whether the sunset clause that applies to the data-matching program should be removed, at least to read the summary of the Auditor-General's report. In particular, I ask the Green senators, the Democrat senator responsible for taking social security legislation through, and Senator Harradine, to read this summary and to decide for themselves whether we should let that sunset clause go. Should we say, `No; we still want to have a sunset clause to say that there is a period after which we may not accept this data-matching process'?

I am sure that any honourable senator who takes the time to read the summary will have no doubt and will conclude that the sunset clause should be extended and that the agencies that are involved in this program should continue to be required to provide the parliament with detailed annual reports in relation to their implementation of the data-matching act. Those amendments went through the Senate to ensure that the Senate would be fully informed about what I believe is a very intrusive investigation into people's personal financial matters.

We required that the agencies table their reports here. That has assisted us greatly in understanding exactly how that process is working, except, as we found out, the Auditor-General has implied that they have not been as transparent as they ought to have been in those reports. They have lifted their game in the recent report because of the not so gentle reminder from the Auditor-General. I call on honourable senators to read the summary of this report. I commend it to them, especially given the decision that we have to make in the chamber in the next day or two.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

This bill amends the Australian Land Transport Development (the ALTD Act) Act 1988 to extend the operation of the Australian Land Transport Development Trust Fund.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government is allocating some $2.46 billion to fund roadworks on National Highways over the three calendar years from 1 January 1994. This amendment will allow this to be funded from the ALTD Act 1988 until new legislation is in force governing the new roads program.

This amendment will not alter the Government's commitment to develop a new National Highway Act during 1994 to replace the ALTD Act 1988. The National Highway Act will create a more efficient road management system, with potentially great benefits to the tax-payer and road users.
As part of this Government's commitment to creating an appropriate roads administration program, a full consultative process is underway involving State Governments and major industry bodies.

Also, in developing the National Highway Bill, the Government will be taking into account reports from the Australian National Audit Office and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport and Communications Infrastructure, both due to report to Parliament later this year.

As a result, the National Highway Bill for the post-1993 roads program will probably be introduced near the end of the current period of sittings, or early in the following period, with consideration and passage in 1994. Hence it is necessary to amend the ALTD Act to extend its operation and ensure that the Federal roads program can continue to be delivered.

The introduction of this amendment will not alter the Government's intention to fund the National Highway System only from 1 January 1994. This commitment arose from the July 1991 Premiers' Conference where it was agreed that road funding responsibility for each level of Government should be more clearly defined and that each tier of Government should concentrate on funding, planning and building roads that were clearly their responsibility.
To provide the Government with the ability to extend the current ALTD Act, three sunset clauses within the Act require amendment:
.subsection 12(1) provides that road user revenue payments into the Trust Fund may only be made before 1 January 1994;
.subsection 12(2) provides that a proportion of refunds applicable to road user charges payable before 1 January 1994, be offset against road user charges payable into the Trust Fund; and
.section 25 provides that the Trust Fund shall be closed at the end of 30 June 1994.
The provisions of this amendment remove each of these final dates and give effect to a continuation of current ALTD Trust Fund arrangements.
The proposed new National Highway Act would contain provisions for the closure of the ALTD Trust Fund.
Turning to details of the bill, clauses 1 and 2 contain the usual citation and commencement provisions.
Clause 3(a) of the bill provides for the continuation of road user charge revenue payments into the Trust Fund beyond the date of 1 January 1994 which would otherwise apply.

Clause 3(b) of the bill likewise provides for the continuation of the provision contained in subsection 12(2) of the Act such that, the proportion of refunds applicable to road user charges payable after 31 December 1993, be offset against road user charges payable into the Trust Fund.

Clause 4 of the bill provides for the continuation of the ALTD Trust Fund for an indefinite period or until it is repealed by the inclusion of an appropriate clause in a new act for administration of the Federal roads program. The Trust Fund would otherwise close at the end of 30 June 1994.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was addressing this particular legislation this morning before we were required, as a Senate, to deliver the address-in-reply to the Governor-General. I was drawing attention to the response in the House of Representatives to the precedents that had been highlighted by and commented on by my colleague the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Daryl Williams. Mr Williams commented on those precedents and assertions in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks first at the Public Service Act provision, it can be seen that this is a provision which protects a person in the preparation of a report in the course of employment where it is done in good faith. It is not a provision that relates to the publication of a report; it relates to the preparation. One might want to argue that, in that respect, it merely restates the common law. To that extent, it might be suggested validly that it constitutes a precedent, but it is not in any way relevant to a situation where, a report or statement having been prepared in the ordinary course of the work of a department, the minister then elects to make it public.

PARA.TAB: It is that issue which is addressed in the proposed addition to section 14J of the principal act.

If one looks at section 91 of the Freedom of Information Act, one finds that this also does not relate to the publication of a document at all except in a very narrow sense. It provides that no action for defamation or other specified forms of action lies against the Commonwealth, an agency, a minister or an officer by reason of the authorising or giving of the access to a document pursuant to the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act.

That is not a general publication; that is almost tantamount to a private publication because it is made to one person: an applicant. It is not, in that sense, as it is under the proposed addition to section 14J, a general publication or the making of information or a statement available to the public.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Williams went on to suggest that neither provision constitutes a precedent for what is sought to be done here. Given that there are no precedents for this action, why does the government claim that it is now necessary in this case? What actions have been taken by the minister in the past against this clause? Neither of these questions has been adequately answered by the minister or by the parliamentary secretary, and I am hoping that the minister in this chamber may be able to shed some light on this particular matter.

PARA.TAB: The second reading speech refers to the fact that this amendment will save litigation costs. Of course, if people are barred from suing, litigation costs are saved. It has made us curious as to just how much litigation has been incurred by the minister when carrying out his duties or attempting to carry out his duties in relation to this area.

Finally, this is not a case of what has happened in the past. It is a case of what the minister anticipates or contemplates will happen in the future. Does the minister expect to deal differently with relevant organisations in the future or does he know something about the intentions of certain organisations or individuals towards him and about legal action that might thus be precluded?

We certainly have the right to be very suspicious of the unprecedented and unnecessary actions that are currently being proposed under clause 4 in this particular piece of legislation. The second reading speech claims that an effect of this clause would be to save litigation costs. At least it says it should save litigation costs. There is a difference between `does' and `should'. Litigation costs are saved if the action is won. Under the present law as it relates to defamation, if one is sued unsuccessfully by someone then one can claim costs against that person. On the other hand, if a person's suing is successful, then it is open to that person to apply for an order for costs.

I do not see the justification of the argument for the need for this clause as being to save costs. Persons save costs if they are in the right. If the minister is acting properly under the act and he is authorised to do a number of things under the act, then that should not be a problem. However, if this clause is intended to extend the ability of the minister to behave in certain ways which would otherwise lead to defamation actions, I fear that this could lead to a very substantial and serious reduction in rights that are available to Australian citizens now.

I have received representations from some very concerned organisations in the disability portfolio area. Minister Howe has not consulted with the organisations representing people with disabilities about this clause. They are extremely concerned that the minister may well use this particular clause to his own advantage and that it will lead to serious reductions in the rights of disability organisations and their members. I am appalled that the government has unsuspectingly used the Disability Services Act to try to slip in this precedent. It really is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer briefly to what the act presently allows. Section 14J at the moment says that if the minister has made a declaration under section 14G, the minister may make available to the public, in any way the minister thinks fit, any or all of the following information:

SPEECH.PARA: (c)the eligible organisation's name and address;
(d)the name and address of the service that is the subject of the declaration;
(e)the terms of the Minister's declaration under section 14G;
(f)details of the eligible organisation's failure to meet the applicable standards in respect of the provision of the service;
(g)the actions taken in respect of the eligible organisation's failure to meet the applicable standards.

To make that just a little more intelligible, the heading under which this section appears in the act is `Information about Minister's declaration may be made available to the public'. Section 14G, which is referred to in section 14J, appears under the heading `Failure to meet applicable standards in the provision of service'. So it has to do with the withdrawal of funding from those organisations that are not meeting the applicable standards. Section 14G allows the minister to make a declaration stating that the eligible organisation is not meeting the applicable standards in respect of the provision of the service and, consequently, is in breach of the conditions of the grant. That all seems quite reasonable and we have not objected to that in the past.

PARA.TAB: Section 14G, however, goes on to say that the minister must provide a copy of the declaration to the eligible organisation concerned. Section 14H says that the minister must not make a declaration under section 14G unless a disability standards review panel has been established; that the requirements of the orders have been complied with; that the minister has complied with the guidelines in force under section 5 that relate to the making of such a declaration; that an eligible organisation has applied under the orders to the panel for a review; and that the minister, in making the declaration, has had regard to the recommendations made by the panel. That spells it out a little further and shows that the minister has a fair amount of latitude. Section 5, referred to in section 14H, states:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.(1)The Minister must formulate principles and objectives to be furthered and guidelines to be complied with in the administration of this Act.

There is no reference anywhere there to any right of appeal or subsequent hearing which is very important to the consideration of any other precedents that the government may want to offer with regard to other legislation.

PARA.TAB: The minister has a lot of power to decide just what he wants to have happen, which is right and proper. Governments ought to have that power. However, if the minister is of a mind to withdraw someone's grant, then that organisation also has some rights which relate to the disability standards review panel. The minister, however, must only take regard of the recommendations of the panel. He is not bound by them. He can still go ahead and decide not to extend the grant or renew the grant or whatever. He may also make public certain information.

My information is that the minister has qualified privilege under common law. This privilege derives from the fact that he is empowered to do certain things under the act. However, this is qualified to the extent it should be by common law. That common law protects the right of the litigant.
