The best course of action is for the matter to be further examined. There are obviously contrasting legal opinions in relation to this issue. Our advice is different. I am not suggesting that the information given by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) is incorrect; I am just saying that there is a difference in legal advice in relation to this matter. However, I will have the matter further investigated. In the meantime, the best way to proceed is for this clause to be proceeded with. If there is some reason why a change needs to be made, I will recommend to the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson that the change be looked at in the context of the bill proceeding to be dealt with in the Senate.

In making these comments, I am not saying that I accept all of the legal argument given by the opposition, but we need to take on board the legal arguments put and examine the matter further. It is certainly our understanding that they did properly know.

I am also a little disappointed that Victoria should make the points that it did, particularly through Minister Tehan, suggesting that it was not fully consulted. Indeed, Victoria has assisted the federal government very much with this matter because it is the Victorian draft legislation that has been circulated as proposed prospective draft legislation for states and territories to use as part of the complementary legislation that goes with this bill. Indeed, when the current version of these amendments was being discussed with the federal Office of Parliamentary Counsel, an officer from the Victorian Health Department attended that meeting. So it is perhaps a comment that goes to insufficient consultation within the Victorian department, but it is very difficult for the Commonwealth to accept that there was not adequate consultation or adequate information. So I cannot accept those comments from Senator Newman without making my remarks by way of refutation.

Senator Newman also expressed concerns about the grandfathered goods under the TGA. These provisions have been in place since the principal act was put in place, and the amendment contained in clause 52 clarifies but does not change the existing arrangements. Senator Newman really wanted to know exactly what would happen to all the items listed under the grandfathering provision.

The TGA is behaving sensibly in this matter. First of all, it intends to evaluate those grandfathered products if there is a matter of a public health interest. For example, if there were any reported adverse reaction in Australia or even overseas, the good or listed item would be evaluated or a case argued for it to be evaluated by the TGA because the TGA would be concerned to protect the interests of the public in Australia. Secondly, this would also occur if any sponsor of any such good asked for an evaluation by the TGA—indeed, for example, to enhance the status, and perhaps the export potential, of its product. So, apart from that, the TGA will not see its way to moving through every grandfathered good. If grandfathered goods are not covered by a public health concern or if a sponsor does not apply, they will be considered to be listed. So I think that should answer the concerns Senator Newman raised about this matter.

Finally, it is important to note that if a sponsor objected to an evaluation of a grandfathered good, the Senate should know—and, indeed, this legislation makes clear—that the TGA can only enforce such an evaluation through actions under part 3 of the principal act. Decisions under that part of the act are subject to two levels of review: firstly, by my delegates—that is, the people approved to do that on my behalf; and, secondly, by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I am absolutely sure that the TGA has no inclination to misuse its discretion, but I am also equally satisfied that there is a formal accountability process in place should there be that kind of objection.

I believe that Senator Newman raised the matter of silicone injections. The TGA has acted to see that that product has been listed before the drugs and poisoning scheduling, and it is now recommended for listing as a poison. In fact, that means it is listed as a poison. That should allay the people's concerns—particularly Senator Newman's but also certainly mine and others'—that the women of Australia might have been subject to injection by silicone not knowing the negative effects of it. But, in fact, the more concerning matter is that very often they were not advised that it was a silicone injection.

So, clearly, having moved to have that listed as a poison ought to offer protection and some assurance to the community. Senator Newman suggests that there was some delay in having that implemented. But, since the matter has been drawn to my attention, the TGA acted expeditiously in getting that process up and running when it did move for its listing.

The other matter raised in this place by Senator Lees—and I did not have the opportunity to hear all of her contribution—I believe goes very much to the same issue that Senator Tambling raised; that is, clause 4 of the bill. Let me make it clear that what the government was trying to do with the original paragraph was to make clear on the face of the legislation the immunity which the minister already enjoys. It was not the intention to extend the immunity that the Minister might enjoy, but to make explicit that he does have an immunity under the law as it is. That immunity has been confirmed by the Attorney-General's Department.

The proposed amendment would not have extended the minister's immunity beyond statements made in good faith. However, as there appears to be a misunderstanding about this provision and because both Senator Lees and Senator Tambling have made their position quite clear, the government will withdraw the original clause 4 and replace it. The amendment that the government is proposing has been circulated to honourable senators.

I understand that Senator Tambling is not comfortable with the proposed amendment. I would certainly be happy to hear what Senator Lees and the Democrats think of it. The replacement clause extends the common law to ensure that the publication of the minister's statement in good faith enjoys immunity from defamation. I note Senator Tambling's comment earlier that, if the words `in good faith' were explicit, it would cause less difficulty.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that was in relation to the minister; not this bit.

—If I understand Senator Tambling's comment across the chamber, `in good faith' only applies to the minister. Let me make it clear: the replacement clause 4 extends the common law to ensure that the publication of the minister's statement in good faith enjoys immunity from defamation. If we do not replace clause 4 with the government's preferred amendment, the Attorney-General's Department advises that, except in limited circumstances, there is no protection from defamation for people who repeat the information contained in the minister's statement; nor is there any protection for any subsequent publisher.

PARA.TAB: Without the protection offered by the replacement clause, people with a disability, their families and carers may never know if the service they use or want to use falls short of accepted standards. In effect, they would be denied access to the information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does it have to be put in defamatory terms?
—In the end what we may be deciding here is a balance of rights—the rights of people to have access to that information versus the rights of people to have their good name protected.
—In defamatory terms.

—Senator Tambling cannot keep insisting that publishing facts about a centre—particularly if the review panel's analysis and examination conclude that it is insufficient or not up to standard—cannot be taken, on the face of it, as defamation. What is of concern is that if there is no protection for that information to be made more widely known, then families of a disabled person may not be able to assess whether or not that service falls short of accepted standards. They would be denied access to the information. Anyone else who publishes the minister's statement about the service may be liable to defamation action. The defence of fair report may not be available to, for example, self-help groups or a parent network which want to republish the minister's statement under section 14J.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that a precedent for the replacement clause 4 is subsection 134A(4) of the National Health Act 1953. Senator Tambling and Senator Lees have raised concerns about this matter. The government did take note of those concerns. It has agreed to withdraw clause 4 and replace it in an amended form. The proposed amendment will remove any doubt about the immunity the minister enjoys, but it also insists on putting into the law a protection against claims of defamation for people who might publish the information or even, indeed, mention it.

Two points need to be understood about this matter: firstly, the people who might actually announce, circulate or want to publish that information have the protection from defamation; and, secondly, that the family of a person with a disability also ought to have access to that information. In the end, it is, I think, a matter of balance and a matter of judgment.

Those opposite should note from the government's response that the comments made in the House of Representatives have been taken seriously as indeed, one would have to say, has the substance of the comments made by Senator Tambling in his contribution here as well as those made by Senator Lees. I ask that honourable senators opposite give serious consideration to the government's amended clause 4. We understand that it addresses the principal concerns raised by opposition senators and by the opposition in the other place.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) in her closing remarks referred to the fact that I would wish to oppose clause 4 and therefore delete it. Alternatively, the minister proposed that the government would subsequently move an amendment which only picked up part of the effect of what my action would achieve; that is, the removal of the clause in toto. The minister made a number of statements that I do not believe fully understand the issues that were raised by Mr Daryl Williams QC and Mrs Sullivan in the House of Representatives, nor the concerns that we expressed here.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I accept that the government's circulated draft amendment may well improve the drafting and may seek to address some of the issues that we have raised, in effect the minister has not answered any of the series of questions that we put to her with regard to the need for the clause and the issues relating to why a minister under this particular legislation should have any more protection from defamatory action than any other minister of the Crown. The chamber will recall that the original justification for this clause was a very unusual provision to protect the minister in this particular case. It was very much a matter of special protection. We did not get any indication of the types of statements that could be made, said or subsequently published.

It is still our concern and our suspicion that this legislation protects the minister in such a way that it is really nothing more than a licence to badmouth particular organisations. It is very important to draw on the concerns that I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate that had been addressed by the disability peak organisations. I incorporated in Hansard letters from ACROD Ltd and the Association for Disability Employment, Placement and Training Ltd. Both organisations said that they had very serious concerns about that particular issue. The ADEPT letter, written by a Mr Byrne, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Too often, services for people with disabilities have been attacked in the media with little, or no, foundation resulting in considerable damage to the services' reputation and the quality of service for people with disabilities.

In her closing comments the minister also referred to a number of issues with regard to subsequent publication. But that takes us back to the point of irony, the very point of intent—that the minister has initially made a statement that may well be defamatory and the fact that the original statement is of itself defamatory and is then requiring this subsequent area. Regarding the replacement clause the minister is proposing, she said:
. . . people with a disability, their families and carers may never know if the service they use or want to use falls short of accepted standards.

I accept that that is something the minister should be conveying and something which should be done, but it need not be done in a manner that is defamatory. It is inherently consistent and proper for the government and the minister to ensure that it is not done in a process that just protects a government that does want to take that licence to bag and to proceed in that area.

PARA.TAB: We need to look very carefully at the issue that the minister referred to in the area of precedent. The precedent the government is arguing and quoting from for the replacement of clause 4 is subsection 134A(4) of the National Health Act 1953. The coalition certainly remains concerned with this precedent. Subsection 134A(4) refers to actions taken under sections 33, 35, 95 and 133 of the National Health Act 1953. It is interesting to note that sections 33 and 35 have now been deleted from the original act. Section 95 of the National Health Act allows that, after investigation and report by the appropriate committee of inquiry in order to reprimand a medical practitioner, the minister may publish particulars in the gazette. Quite clearly, both sides of the case are heard, that of the government and that of the medical practitioner.

Section 133 of the National Health Act relates to a medical practitioner, dental practitioner or approved pharmacist being charged before a court having committed an offence against the National Health Act. There is a very big difference between the defunding of disability services that are being provided and this argument—they relate to two different issues. A medical professional charged before a court has all other rights of appeal, similarly with an investigation and reprimand of a medical practitioner. But there are certain rights of appeal that are not available in the process that is proposed for this legislation for the disability review standards.

If we look closely at the Disability Services Act 1986, we see that there is a fundamental flaw in this legislation. It would appear that under this act the Disability Standards Review Panel meets to review the funding situation of the disability service organisation. However, once the review panel meets and makes its recommendations on a disability service, provided there is no right of reply for the disability service provider to defend itself against the review contained in the Disability Services Act, the minister can make a statement without the right of reply from the disability service provider. This is also unprecedented. The minister is protected, anything that is published is protected, and the disability service provider has no right of reply. I fail to see how this can be considered fair for the disability service providers and their organisations.

The government's proposed amendment, which may be considered after the one I am now speaking to, does not address this issue. It comes back to this very fundamental flaw. It does not go to the heart of the concerns that are being addressed by the disability service provider. Therefore, we cannot support the amendment proposed by the government. In fact, we would argue that the only way to properly achieve the proper outcomes—the equity, the fairness and the justice to all concerned—is to support my motion that the clause be opposed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this amendment, although, as I outlined earlier, it covered our initial concerns and we did intend to support it.

PARA.TAB: The government's proposed amendment is rather late. It would have been nice, after the original concerns were expressed in the House of Representatives, to have had much of the debate and discussion now going on in the chamber with a variety of legal people and departmental representatives. But at least we now have the government acknowledging that it messed it up in the first place. We now have the core of the problem covered.

I have seen the letters that Senator Tambling has been referring to. The organisations were asked about the original clause. They have not been approached—we have not had time to approach them—with the government's subsequent proposed amendment. My reading of those letters, and our discussions and advice, lead me to believe that the government's amendment basically covers the concern that while the minister did not really need any extra powers at all, anyone who wished to comment on or publish what the minister had said did need some support.

After listening to Senator Tambling's comments, I must stress that people have not suddenly gone into some facility and closed it down; it has been a long, drawn-out process during which all parties have had the opportunity to put their case and argue their point of view. Unfortunately, we do have an act that allows for facilities to be closed down as a last resort. Unfortunately, we do have facilities that are not meeting, or certainly in the past have not met, the very basic human rights provisions and basic standards that we deem to be necessary. I stress that, while we are opposing this amendment, we welcome the government's proposed amendment, which we believe basically covers the problem that we are faced with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate, in a similar fashion, that we will be supporting the government's proposed amendment, which we feel does address the concerns that have been raised. But I have some questions on a different section, which is part 8 of clause 52(c)(6), which covers lines 32 to 37 of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). In what instances would the Commonwealth be liable for loss, damage or injury caused by or arising out of the use by persons of therapeutic goods? What would this liability entail?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the purpose of the amendment is to make absolutely clear that the Commonwealth is liable for tested goods but it has no liability, or should not be liable for, ill effects or consequences from untested goods.
—Further to that, what procedures have to be followed before a therapeutic good can be marketed in Australia? Are the criteria for assessment available for public scrutiny?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Senator Chamarette, we are dealing with the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). Are you asking questions to that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am. I was a little bit in doubt, but I think that if I do not take my chance right now I might miss it. I understand we have been discussing the amendment to part 4, but I wish to discuss part 8, clause 52(c)(6), which is the last clause of the bill. If it is more appropriate to first vote on the amendment that is under discussion and then ask my questions, that is fine. As I understand it, this is my time and if I do not say anything, I will lose it.
—You are correct. You may proceed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —In summary, the procedure for goods to be marketed in Australia entails a complex series of processes. The sponsor of a therapeutic good, device or pharmaceutical makes an application to the TGA, and the TGA examines literature and research, et cetera, to make sure that it can satisfy itself as to the quality, safety and efficacy of goods for the purposes for which the application has been made.

PARA.TAB: Clause 25 on page 23 of the Therapeutic Goods Act deals with this procedure. I wonder whether it might be better to offer a more comprehensive briefing to Senator Chamarette outside this debate about the processes of the TGA. I would be very happy to provide that. Once a good is approved by the TGA, it then has to be submitted to the Australian drug evaluation committee, where evidence put to it is further examined. It may then be approved for marketing. From there, it may well proceed to, for instance, the pharmaceutical benefits advisory committee, if it is a pharmaceutical product. There are different processes if it is a good or a device. I suggest that we could be here for a very long time if I took Senator Chamarette through the full process. I wonder whether she would be happy to accept instead an offer for a very detailed briefing about the functions of the TGA.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) for that offer of a briefing. I would be more than willing to receive it. However, I did want these questions to go on the public record, because I believe that there may be an instance here requiring the further scrutiny of the process by which these goods are listed. That is especially so since the clause that is under discussion in this bill makes no provision for the liability of the Commonwealth, the secretary or any delegate of the secretary in respect of loss, injury or damage through the use of these therapeutic goods.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to delay the Senate any longer than is necessary. It is important to put on the record and flag the fact that I am interested in a more detailed briefing and in discussing the question of whether an inquiry may be an appropriate follow-up examination of the basis on which this clause was inserted and the kind of protection that the community will be afforded.

My final questions relate to the procedures. What measures are in place to ensure the ongoing quality, safety and efficacy of therapeutic goods listed on the Australian therapeutic goods register? Is there a requirement for the regular monitoring and review of goods in the light of current and new research in the relevant field? Rather than giving me a long briefing, perhaps the minister can tell me whether there are monitoring procedures in place and what kind of access is available to new information and research on particular products? I know that the minister will be particularly concerned, because silicone implants for breasts are listed on the therapeutic goods register and, of course, there has been some controversy about the research findings in relation to them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two ways in which products are subjected to ongoing monitoring. Senator Chamarette has nodded because she would know what that involves. Firstly, any reporting of adverse reactions to medication or drugs is brought directly to the attention of the TGA through the adverse drug reaction advisory committee. Secondly, there is the random monitoring of goods that have been registered and approved, particularly to see that they maintain manufacturing standards, et cetera. Perhaps we should offer a more comprehensive briefing to Senator Chamarette and take her through the process.

PARA.TAB: She asked whether a further inquiry is needed. I am sure that that question has just sent a massive shiver through the TGA representatives, because the TGA is not long out of a very comprehensive inquiry conducted by former senator Peter Baume. I take this opportunity to commend that inquiry by Peter Baume. It covered the sorts of questions that Senator Chamarette is asking and reviewed many of the TGA's processes. The most important outcome was Peter Baume's recommendation, which has since been adopted, for the timeliness of the testing of therapeutic goods. In times past, there has been a long lead time, which has been a cause of frustration. That has been changed as a result of the Baume inquiry. A second recommendation provides the opportunity for the TGA to make use of research and information provided about any of the products brought before the TGA from overseas. So it is not entirely a process of reinventing the wheel. It is about making use of information that is available to allow the process to be speeded up while in no way jeopardising the safety of those products or the reliability of the TGA's testing.

I believe that we can be fairly sure that Australia offers very good protection in the whole therapeutic area through the processes of the TGA. Certainly, I suggest that there is no immediate need for an inquiry. All but two recommendations of the Baume inquiry have been implemented. It was a very recent inquiry and it has blown the winds of change through the TGA. The timeliness of the procedure is clear evidence of those new processes being put in place to the benefit of the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned that the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) has not addressed the series of questions that we have raised. We have raised a series of questions in the second reading debate, both in the House of Representatives and here, which go to the fundamentals of why the legislation was needed and under what circumstances it would be anticipated that the minister would have to exercise, or may well need the protection of, this legislation relating to possible defamations.

PARA.TAB: No reasons have been given why this minister, under this act, needs protection that is not available to any other minister of the crown under any other legislation that achieves similar aims and objectives. That issue has not been addressed by the minister. I am disappointed that Senator Crowley has not been in a position to give us a comprehensive coverage of those areas where this would be sought.

Similarly, I address the issue of the precedents on which the government is seeking to rely. Very clearly, we established that the precedents that were quoted in the House of Representatives were inadequate, inoperable and did not apply. Today, in the lunchtime paper that was distributed, we were given another precedent, which I have now pointed out, relating to different issues, such as medical practitioners, charges and certain rights of appeal in the processes.

The Disability Services Act does not provide for any of those subsequent rights of appeal. I am very disappointed that Senator Chamarette and Senator Lees have indicated that they will not be able to fully support this legislation because I believe a very fundamental issue of law is involved and that the government is cheating by now seeking to hide behind that issue in the passage of this legislation.

This legislation will create an unprecedented and unnecessary camouflage and protection for the minister in this issue. I would like to have on the record the justification for the minister seeking to rely on the precedent that was quoted today, which relates to the National Health Act; how that in any way is comparable or relates to the legislation before us; and how the proposed amendment that was cobbled together at lunchtime will achieve the objectives of the government.

The fundamental issue is how the minister can go out and make a defamatory statement and hide behind that protection when no other minister can. I certainly accept the principle that we might want to protect other people who get caught up because of the defamation of the minister. But I cannot accept that the amendment before us does that. It relies on very false premises.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly try to assist Senator Tambling. I am advised that subsection 134A(4) of the National Health Act that I referred to, which does not refer to nursing home standards, provides an example of this type of protection for people who further publish reports. So it is analogous in that way. It was provided by way of assistance to senators in understanding that this is not a matter without precedent.

PARA.TAB: I am interested that Senator Tambling would be still concerned when our amendment very much goes to accepting the points of concern that he has raised, vis-a-vis the minister particularly. Senator Tambling has said again and again that the minister can rush out and make defamatory statements. I am advised that what the minister can say is actually spelt out in the legislation. The type of information that the minister may publish is prescribed in the legislation. I am not quite sure where Senator Tambling gets the sense that this allows the minister to rush around the place trawling defamatory statements behind him or her.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you need the clause?

It also ensures the protection of people who may publish those statements in good faith or who may even make a comment about those statements. It is, as I said before, a matter of considerable importance that the community have access to the information and that the people publishing that information in good faith are also protected.

PARA.TAB: I am not talking about a wild body of statements that is defamatory but information that is prescribed in the legislation. That is what those statements would be. I am not sure that I can offer anything more to calm Senator Tambling's anxiety on this matter. I think we have taken very serious note of what the opposition raised by way of objection. We have gone to the point of actually amending clause 4 so as to take account of Senator Tambling's principal concern, but we have maintained a protection which we feel is very necessary, on the advice of the Attorney-General, to protect people who publish in good faith.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—The question that will be put is that clause 4 stand as printed. But honourable senators should note that the government amendment is consequential upon clause 4 being omitted. I put the question that clause 4 stand as printed.

I am looking to the clerk-assistant, Mr Elliott, for advice here. I acted in this manner because I believed that the clause was not agreed to.

—How can the minister move an amendment to a clause if it is not there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

—His was not an amendment; it was a direct opposition to the clause.
—Originally I moved that the clause be opposed. It was therefore on the form of the motion that I wished to exercise a division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 is just another law and justice legislation amendment bill. Like all others, it is an omnibus bill that seeks to make amendments to a variety of other substantive bills. Most of the amendments in this case—and I suppose in all others—are an attempt to bring one or more bills into line with others to bring some sort of consistency to the manner in which we deal with a particular subject across a range of bills. That is not always done at one time. When it is not done at one time, the bills that have not been made consistent are brought up on another occasion in an amending bill, such as the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill.

PARA.TAB: These omnibus bills are also used to make minor technical amendments that are not judged as being meritorious or important enough to have a bill of their own to take up the time of the parliament. So they are just tucked into one of these amending bills. This bill has some of those minor technical amendments as well.

They also inevitably have what are politely referred to as drafting errors. I suppose that is what they are in substance. This omnibus bill is no exception, as there are a number of so-called drafting errors to be corrected. I would like to spend a couple of minutes referring to some of those drafting errors. It is an opportune time to do so while the parliament—both the Senate and the House of Representatives—is considering new procedures for how we conduct our business. The debate has been not so much raging, but at least it has been occurring and this issue has been raised in that debate.

The quality of the work that we do in this place—not just what we as senators and members in the other place do, but what we expect of the Public Service—fits a timetable which is, by and large, decided by executive whim. It is widely acknowledged that as a consequence of our failure, collectively, to set up sensible arrangements for dealing with legislation, mistakes are made. Sometimes they are not mistakes that necessarily more time would have picked up, albeit we would like to think more time, if it had been allowed, would have allowed those mistakes to be picked up.

I use as an example the recent changes to the Bankruptcy Act which occurred in the last session, when I think there was unanimous agreement to some changes in order to get at the assets of bankrupts who stash assets away in one way or another. Such was the political climate at the time that everybody wanted to get stuck into these people; a bill was rushed through this place and was later found to be unconstitutional.

When the unconstitutional aspect was pointed out, a number of people said, `Its as clear as a bell; anyone could see that'. Perhaps if we had had a bit more time, anyone would have seen it. The Public Service that drafted the bill might have spotted it; the executive to which the bill was given might have spotted it; the opposition, which had some opportunity, albeit limited, to look at it, might have spotted it, as might the Democrats, Senator Harradine and the Greens. But it did not happen, so we had to rush through a separate amendment.

That is not the category of mistake that has been made in this bill. These drafting errors are not brought about by and large through incompetence—although I suppose some might be unkind enough to say that—but by incapacity to run this place properly and to set aside enough time for the Public Service to do the job it wants to do and can do. We could all be idealistic and say that we hope one day that that is the job that the House of Representatives would like to do rather than it just being the house of the executive. Certainly the job that this chamber and its committees would like to do is pick up these sorts of drafting errors. That will happen only when we have more time and a more sensible arrangement is arrived at for the reference of bills to committees.

The practice has developed to refer to committees matters that are a bit complicated. I sometimes wonder whether senators who do not have a heavy committee load put their minds at rest and think that an all-seeing, all-knowing committee will be looking at the particular matter. Perhaps those committees would if they had the time.

We send these bills to committees in the hope of getting a better assessment of both the policy impact and substantive detail of the bill. The system we use to send bills to committees is very good: not only does each bill get additional consideration that it otherwise would not; it is a means whereby members of the public and particular interest groups can put their points of view as well. I do not mean to be completely negative about the process of sending bills to committees; but it does not always work because we do not allow enough time.

A collection of bright sparks get together on a Tuesday and decide that a bill will be referred to a committee and it will be considered on the following Friday. So on Wednesday, if we are lucky, or Thursday morning someone hops on the phone and rings around and says, `Do you think you can whiz up to Canberra on Friday?'. That is basically how it works. Members of lobby groups based in Canberra can drop their morning tea and cinnamon cake and pop over. But not everybody that the parliament might like to consult lives in Canberra—much to some people's surprise—and consequently the very limited time frame on reporting back means that not all the groups who would like to have a say can.

Having used this opportunity to get that off my chest, I will refer to the drafting errors that are contained in this bill. According to the explanatory memorandum, clause 20 of this bill rectifies a drafting error of the amendment of section 36 in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Act 1992 to remove the requirement that an acting race discrimination commissioner shall not continue so to act for more than 12 months. I am a bit suspicious as to whether that is in fact a drafting error or a change of policy. I need not make a point on it. Sometimes it is very convenient to call things drafting errors when in fact they are not.

Clause 22 rectifies a drafting omission in the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Act 1992. Clause 22 will amend the reference in subsection 13(2) of the act from section 28 to section 28B. I think that is because there is no section 28 and the bill needs to read 28B. It thereby restores the exemption from the sexual harassment in work provisions for employees of a state or a state instrumentality. That amendment will be taken to have commenced in January of this year, which is the date the Sex Discrimination and other Legislation Amendment Act actually commenced. That is nothing other than a drafting error. Someone was meant to put in 28B and did not.

I have not had the time to look, but London to a brick the person who did that was working under time pressures, did not mean to make the mistake and was not an incompetent idiot; the person simply was not given the right opportunity to do the job. We may say, `So what? It is no big deal; why go on about it?'. I do not mean to go on about the substance of the errors, but I simply say this is another example of things not being done properly because people are not given the proper time to do their job properly.

Equally, clause 23 will rectify a drafting error to renumber subsection 14(4), inserted by section 2 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Act 1992, subsection 14(3A). This amendment is necessary because subsections 14(4) and 14(6) were inserted. They are the three drafting errors that I have picked up and perhaps there are others.

It is worth mentioning also that I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which has a cost of justice reference. The cost of justice issue has become very popular and is one that is discussed over any cup of coffee or any dinner table. The most fashionable entry to that discussion is to get stuck into the legal profession. Very rarely do I hear my colleagues such as Senator Bolkus—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are always relating stories from the dinner table. We never stop hearing them.

—We will come back to that one. The most popular way to enter into the cost of justice issue is to get stuck into lawyers. Many people believe that lawyers earn too much and that the law is a hated profession. It may well be that law is a hated profession, but I do not think it is correct that lawyers earn too much.

PARA.TAB: But we in this place very rarely like to turn our minds to the fact that we contribute to increasing costs. A good example is a poor law clerk in a firm who is given the job of drafting an opinion in relation to one of these bills that has the wrong numbering. That clerk would spend some time on that. Those opposite might say that 20 minutes is not a long time and that the poor dope should have rung someone more senior and had it checked out more quickly. Do those opposite know who pays for the 20 or 30 minutes or hour of that law clerk's time that was spent chasing up something because we messed it up?

It is not just the volume of legislation that is passed through this place, it is the quality of legislation—whether it is in plain English and whether these sorts of errors are made—that is the problem. All around Australia this is costing somebody to try to interpret acts of parliament that have been badly drafted. This is not out of bad faith but because of inadequate time. We all pay for this in some way through our taxes, but by and large it is the taxpayers who pay for our incompetence in that respect.

We should give ourselves a bit of a serve rather than pick on lawyers all the time for the poor job that we do. Every one of these little errors makes a difference. They add to the costs of people trying to divine what it was that parliament meant. Parliament cannot even print the legislation properly. We have to add on the cost of fixing up this legislation.

Officers in the Attorney-General's Department spot the error and think, `When can we fix that up?' They draft a report which someone considers; it is then decided that an amendment should be made, but to which bill? A committee meeting is held to decide whether to include it in an omnibus bill or put it into another one.

We could have a law and justice amendment bill every session and we could plan for 10 years ahead and we still would not get through all the things that have to be fixed up. This is an appalling state of affairs for which this government on its own is not responsible. We are all responsible for that deplorable situation.

The coalition will move amendments to clauses 7, 10 and 11 of the bill. They are amendments to the section of the Privacy Act which deals with representative complaints. These amendments seek to take out section 7(a) and to insert a new definition of `class member' in section 7(b). We will be voting against clauses 10 and 11. Obviously the purpose of these amendments is to negate the changes that the government is seeking to make. We believe that this change ought not be made. We do not consider it appropriate that an action should be taken on someone's behalf when that person is able to opt out. Rather, we think that when group actions are taken, people should have to opt in. It is for that reason we seek to move these amendments. I am not sure that we will get much support; we did not last time when we expressed the same view. Nonetheless, we will proceed.

These are the only areas in which we seek to make an amendment to the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill. We are happy to allow the government to proceed with a number of other matters, not the least of which are changes to the Privacy Act relating to disclosures of credit information by credit providers to state and territory government authorities, together with minor amendments to the High Court and other matters.

I understand that the Greens will seek through this bill to amend the Freedom of Information Act. We received those amendments late yesterday and will not be supporting them. But I have indicated to the Greens that we believe that the Freedom of Information Act requires some serious consideration. I understand that the Greens are intending to proceed with those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—The key aspect will put a cap on the amount of money that one is required to pay and also will make provision at no cost to parliamentarians for freedom of information requests.
—Yes.

—That properly explains what the Greens would like to do. It is notionally quite attractive to put a cap on these things, but if one had bad faith or was simply a bit incompetent, one might easily draft a request, the expense of which would be so far in excess of $100 that charging that amount would be a waste of time. I think there needs to be some sensible charge. That charge needs to have some reasonable correlation to what is being asked for from government. One cannot expect to have as of right access to any amount of information that one would like at the expense of other taxpayers. In my view, it should not be thought of as the government paying. It is other taxpayers who will pay if extraordinary requests, to be acquired for a fee of only $100, are acceded to.

PARA.TAB: That also has some quite immediate attraction for parliamentarians, no doubt flowing from this government's continual policy of depriving members of parliament of as much information as it possibly can. I remember back in 1987 when the Prime Minister, probably on the back of a table napkin, developed the Priority One program to assist young Australians. I had to pay a significant amount of money to get access to that information. We should not have to pay huge amounts of money to get information. I am not saying we should we have it for nothing; after all, it is at taxpayers' expense. But we do need to find a way to ensure that parliamentarians can get the proper information so that they can make proper decisions in this place.
In conclusion, I point out again that I will be moving those amendments in the committee stage, and that we are happy to support the other aspects of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. This bill addresses a number of minor amendments in the Disability Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act, the Sex Discrimination Act, the Privacy Act and the High Court of Australia Act. The Australian Democrats will be supporting these amendments which, in part, correct drafting errors, as has been said, and which, in part, streamline the procedures which already exist for enforcing in the Federal Court determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

PARA.TAB: A substantive amendment that gave us some reason to pause relates to the extension of the 28-day time limit which the respondent is given to apply for review of the determination in exceptional circumstances. We have no objection to this amendment, as the complainant is afforded the same rights of review of an unfavourable determination by the commissioner under section 11(1) of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. That was not immediately apparent and there was some concern that the respondent was being afforded a right which was not available at the same time and in the same way to the complainant.

However, there is another concern. Following a determination by the commission in favour of the complainant under any of these four acts, the respondents can continue to offend with impunity until the normal period for application for review has passed, in other words, within the 28 days, or until any review proceedings which were initiated are either completed or terminated.

While the grant of such an effective amnesty is clearly defective, it seems to have arisen as an unfortunate by-product of the government's need to circumvent the possible unconstitutionality of the provisions. As it is unconstitutional for the commission to exercise judicial power, the determination of the commission cannot be regarded as binding until it has been registered in the Federal Court and the optional period for review has either transpired or been utilised. Unfortunately, it would seem that it is therefore impossible to cure the defect of the `amnesty' provided to the offender by amending these procedures.

The amendments to the representative complaints proceedings in the Privacy Act which are proposed in the bill will bring the act into line with the Disability Discrimination Act, the Sex Discrimination Act and the Racial Discrimination Act procedures. Given that the determinations which the commission makes pursuant to each of these acts are then registered as orders of the Federal Court, it is important that there is not only consistency between the acts but also that they are consistent with standard Federal Court procedures for representative complaints.

In this area the opposition has foreshadowed amendments which the Democrats will not support. We believe it is proper in effective representative proceedings that participants are given the chance to be included and to opt out if they do not wish to be included.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have still got the chance to be included the other way.

—It is not quite the same. It does not make the procedures as effective. The Democrats will certainly not support the amendments. The proposed amendments to the High Court of Australia Act 1979 simply streamline the administration of the court by avoiding duplication of functions in the clerk's and registrar's roles. The Democrats will support these amendments as well.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the amendments which have been proposed by the Western Australian Greens seeking to amend the Freedom of Information Act 1982 by putting a cap on the charges that can be made for a freedom of information request and removing the section which allows the minister to provide a conclusive certificate if a particular document is to be excluded from the freedom of information request. I will deal with the details of that more clearly in the committee stage.

Let me say, though, that both these amendments are extremely familiar, having been initiated, approved or moved by the Democrats on seven or eight occasions during the last few years whenever freedom of information legislation has come before the Senate. We welcome their reappearance on these grounds and we certainly support them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments circulated in my name, as has been mentioned, relate to the Freedom of Information Act. I will be moving the amendments in the committee stage. They have been foreshadowed as a means of addressing the situation which has been around for a long time whereby it is very difficult for a number of people in the community to gain access to policy documents. We are aware that there are no fees or charges for documents relating to a person's personal affairs or income security payments for pensions but in terms of policy documents substantial charges can occur. Even a small request could result in a charge of $500-plus. The charges relate to a $30 application fee, which is fine, a $15 an hour search and retrieval fee—maybe, although it does not exactly streamline the process—and a $20 an hour decision making fee.

PARA.TAB: We wonder whether this is an incentive for bureaucrats to spend many hours making decisions. Exactly who ends up making the major decisions—which relates to the first part of my amendments—regarding who gets the final say? I noted that Senator Vanstone's remarks were mainly related to the second part of my foreshadowed amendments. Perhaps the first part of my amendments also requires consideration, that is, who gets the final say. Should it be the government or should it be an independent body based on fair and understandable rules that everybody knows about? So in foreshadowing the amendments, I ask the opposition to also look at the first part of the amendments, which is separate in its application from the second part of the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes Senator Vanstone's foreshadowed amendments and, in doing so, goes back to the history of this provision and class actions and the whole debate about whether one adopts an opt-in or opt-out proposal. It is a debate that we have had on a number of occasions in the past. It was a debate that was running hot when I was Minister for Consumer Affairs. The government was then considering what sort of approach to take—an opt-in or opt-out approach. We went for the opt-out approach.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Tate, when he was minister, was responsible for legislation going through this parliament on this aspect of legislation. We opted for an opt-out approach because it was much more preferable on grounds of equity and efficiency. It allowed access to many more Australians to assert their rights and was most efficient.

It is a debate that in previous times probably would have generated much more heat and would have had all sorts of groups on either side arguing which of the two options was the most preferred. We took the deliberate policy decision. We felt that legal access to redress of rights—particularly for those who are disadvantaged and less educated, those who have less access to the legal system—was more likely to come through an opt-out proposal which, at the same time as enhancing the access to justice of many, still protected those who wanted to drop out of a particular court action by allowing them to remove themselves from that representative complaint before an inquiry had commenced. Those people were able to commence separate individual complaints if they wished to do so.

In essence, the history of these sorts of actions is that it is a simpler and cheaper process to run if there is an opt-out process. But, more importantly, when it comes to those in our community who do not have access to law—those who have extra barriers towards that access because of language, education or, most importantly, because of resources—an opt-out class action approach is much fairer and enhances their rights of access.

The debate this evening does not have the vitality that we had some five or six years ago and even more recently when Senator Tate introduced legislation. To the extent that we go through the opposition's package of amendments, we are reliving once again past debates. I do not think we should take all that long canvassing it now, given the fact that our history has indicated that massive economic dislocation and massive cost to the economy was going to occur if we went down this road. All those threats and predictions of doom have not eventuated. We have in place a much fairer opting-out process, and the government sticks with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 7, page 3, paragraph (a), lines 30 to 36, omit the paragraph.
2.Clause 7, page 4, paragraph (b), lines 1 to 4, omit the paragraph, substitute:
"class member", in relation to a representative complaint, means any of the individuals referred to in subsection 36(2);".

I understand what Senator Bolkus is saying about the heat being taken out of the debate and the arguments all having been run. I think it is a bit rich to suggest that it necessarily follows that he is more interested in giving access to those who do not now have access, and that he is going to be of greater assistance to people who have other barriers, such as language barriers, that limit their access.

PARA.TAB: One might equally take the flip side of that coin and say that a person with that particular barrier might be at just as much of a disadvantage in accessing the information as to whether he or she should opt out. I really think that Senator Bolkus made a self-serving speech. I take the points he made, but I do not happen to agree with them. Can the minister clarify the point about cost? Not much particularly stands on it for the purposes of this debate since we know how everybody will go, but how is the cost of proceedings dealt with?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The point was about providing people ways to get access to justice and overcoming some of the costs involved in the system. It is not a fresh debate. When we canvassed this particular aspect before the Senate last time there were competing views as to opting in or opting out. The government's view was that an opting out process allows more people to have access in the first instance to a particular cause of action and they get the direct result from that. I think that has been the effect of these sorts of provisions throughout the world.
—But who pays? Does everybody pay? If you opt out, do you have to pay?
—The provisions in terms of paying are already encompassed in the legislation. I do not think that Senator Vanstone's proposal goes to that.
—I know. I am just asking as a matter of interest.

—The proposal, as it worked through this place, was that the primary complainant incurs the cost, but arrangements can be organised through the court to share the costs. That was very much part of the proposal that went through the Senate some two or three years ago.

—Since Senator Bolkus does have access to someone who does know—this is purely for information; I do not intend taking long because I realise there are other things to do—in the situation where someone has not opted out, can that person, not of his or her own volition, end up having to pay some sort of cost? Can the situation eventuate where someone, perhaps with a language barrier or whatever, missed the opportunity to opt out, was a part of this representative action and therefore, at a later date, has to make some sort of contribution?
—My advice is that they do not.

—The Australian Democrats take the view that the opting out process is by far the fairer one. The danger that a person who should be covered by a class action is not included, if the opting in proposal is being used, is far greater than the converse. There is also provision, of course, that people may, if they wish to pursue their own individual action, opt out. The Australian Democrats believe that that is the best way to run a representative action and we shall not be supporting these amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone, I suggest that, as we move to your other proposed amendments, rather than put them as amendments, I call the clauses together on the basis that the clauses stand as printed.

—Mr Chairman, I was hoping the course of action you would take would be that you would put clauses 8 and 9 together and then put clauses 10 and 11 together, if you thought it was appropriate. That would enable the coalition to express its view that clauses 10 and 11 ought to be opposed.

—We are taking the bill as a whole, so we can take the course of action I suggest. We have dealt with the first two of your four amendments. I was proposing, if it be your wish, that I simply call those two clauses individually, that they stand as printed, and you would oppose them rather than have a substantive amendment.
—That is what I am advocating. I seek leave to have those two clauses called together.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everything I wanted to say with respect to these actions I have said. I agree with Senator Bolkus that it has all been said before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I mentioned earlier, I have flagged two amendments to the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. I would like to speak to both of my circulated amendments and move each separately because they are dealing with separate issues and can stand on their own.
—By all means.

—Thank you. James Madison, one of the founders of the American republic, stated that democracy cannot function without the citizens of the democracy having access to the information needed to take part in the political process. This need is even greater today because of the greater complexity of government and the greater intrusion into the lives of individuals by government agencies.

PARA.TAB: In 1982 this parliament passed the Freedom of Information Act after a protracted and difficult gestation. Honourable senators who were involved will probably recall the difficulties. Those of us who were not involved can see the evidence in the committee reports and the speeches made in support of freedom of information, particularly that of the then shadow Attorney-General Gareth Evans.

Despite the best endeavours of all concerned, the Freedom of Information Act that was produced was a flawed creature. It is said that a camel is a horse designed by a committee. This act was not even a camel since a camel is a particularly useful creature in some circumstances. Senator Evans remarked that there was a battle not between the parties in parliament, but between the parliament and the bureaucracy, and the parliament lost.

I turn to the instrument by which the bureaucracy won the infamous internal working documents exemption. I understand that there may be some circumstances in which documents of that class may contain information that should be exempt from release, but these are few and far between. The real hump in this section was the possibility of the issue of a conclusive certificate. This is purely a means of preventing the release of embarrassing material.

To paraphrase what Senator Evans said on 8 April 1981, this is not a freedom of information act, it is a freedom from information act. Section 36, the internal working documents exemption, is the main buttress of this freedom from information. Senator Evans did, in fact, move the very amendment which I am now proposing. It was unfortunately lost, but I am certain that with his support, it will receive a better fate.

The other area in which there needs to be urgent amendment is that of fees and charges. The majority of applications for documents do not attract fees and charges. These are requests for documents relating to the applicant. The requests that attract fees and charges are those for policy documents. For these there is not only an application fee of $30, but also search and retrieval at $15 an hour and decision making at $20 an hour. If ever there was inducement for a bureaucrat to prevaricate and procrastinate, this is it. Not only do applicants not get what they wanted, but also they have to pay for it as well.

In a recent freedom of information request of which I have been made aware, the charge for 200 pages, not all of which were released, was $2,000. That is ludicrous. The entire object of these charges is to deter citizens from applying for access to documents which their taxes have already paid for. Members of the opposition were well aware of this when they prevented the increase in charges by means of regulation in 1987, though they later agreed to the increase when the measure was introduced as part of the budget bill. It is not possible to determine how many people are deterred from lodging requests or how many withdraw their requests after being informed of the charges. This is perhaps a prime example of freedom from information.

I also add at this stage that I know the opposition has stood up strongly for independence for the audit office from the government. On the same principle, freedom of information should act independently of government or ministers being able to intercede to disallow information from being available.

It might be contended that the cost of limiting charges is not borne out by the benefits conferred. However, in 1991-92 the cost of freedom of information was $12.7 million and the amount received in fees was $414,448. It is unlikely that even half of this revenue would be forgone. It is also unlikely that there would have been an explosive increase in the number of requests.

I certainly hope that there will be an increase as this is the object of the amendment, but no matter how many there are, they will not strain the resources of the Commonwealth. Indeed, if freedom of information were used properly to uncover inefficiency and error, it would probably result in an effective increase in the revenues of the Commonwealth. Regardless of the benefit to the body politic of increased access by the people of Australia to the information concerned, the running of their country outweighs any minor increase in outlays. I commend the amendments to the committee and move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.At the end of bill, add the following Part:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "PART 7—AMENDMENTS OF THE FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT 1982

SPEECH.PARA: "42. In this Part, "Principal Act" means the Freedom of Information Act 1982.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Repeal of conclusive certificates for internal working documents

SPEECH.PARA: "43. Sub-sections 36(3) and 36(4) of the Principal Act are repealed.".

Amendment No. 1 specifies the principal act as being the Freedom of Information Act. The second part of the amendment, relating to the repeal of conclusive certificates for internal working documents, is the one to which I was referring in relation to the fact that the current means of gaining information is to first of all make an application. What happens then is, basically, if an exemption is called, a person can appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. A conclusive certificate can then be given. This certifies that a document is exempt and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal cannot review merits of decision. It is restricted decisions on whether the issuing of the conclusive certificate was reasonable.

PARA.TAB: As I mentioned earlier, if documents really are exempt because of material in them, the AAT will find that they are exempt. A conclusive certificate only serves to protect documents which are not really exempt; that is, such things as legal advice, issues of national security and personal privacy, which are protected elsewhere. The AAT should be the one deciding on the merits, as Senator Evans said in 1981. I have moved this amendment on the basis that it is better that an independent body, acting by the rules that we all understand, is the one to decide whether or not information is available to people in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment. It is an amendment that the Democrats have sought to achieve in this chamber for a number of years. The main problem with a conclusive certificate for internal working documents being issued by the minister is that, by issuing that conclusive certificate, the minister essentially has a prima facie case.

PARA.TAB: The review is extremely limited. It is limited to whether the public interest is well served by the minister's decision. It is not possible for contra-arguments on the issue of public interest to be advanced in that review. This means that the balance of public interest which, in such a matter, should be properly addressed, cannot be addressed. We believe that it is not justified to restrict in this way information concerning the process of government that citizens are entitled to. Very clearly, it is one of the principles of democratic government that the process of government is transparent, whereas this provision is clearly designed to make it opaque. The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the amendment. I think we come to this debate, as we did some 12 years ago, and since then, with the need to obtain as much openness as is workable. The Evans proposals at that particular time were geared towards that. I remember being part of, if not chairing, a Senate committee in the early 1980s on the issue of FOI. Once again we addressed the need to balance the interest of openness with the interest of ensuring that—
—Why have you changed your mind?

—No. I just said that we have to balance the needs of those competing interests, as we are now doing. Senator Margetts referred to what Senator Gareth Evans said on this matter, but what Senator Evans said concerned a situation that prevailed some 12 years ago. We have now had 12 years experience with this legislation—or some of us might have had 12 years experience with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Over those 12 years we have seen restraint shown in the use of certificates. We have seen that a minister has the imperative of reporting to parliament when not following AAT recommendations to revoke certificates. But, more importantly, in 1987 a Senate committee reviewed the act and rejected the concept of abolition of conclusive certificates.

We understand where honourable senators opposite are coming from, but we also have the experience of 12 years, together with that 1987 Senate committee report, to indicate to us that a balance has to be maintained. The conclusive certificates have been used only as a last resort in the most sensitive cases. That was a view that was adopted by the Senate committee; it is a view that should be taken by this place when making a decision as to how to handle the amendment moved by the Greens.

The purpose of the amendment is to limit fees—to make the process freedom of information, rather than freedom from information—to a maximum of $100, because we have already paid for this information in our taxes. TALK.START.PARA: —There is very little to add to the arguments that the Australian Democrats have advanced on this issue for a number of years. We simply say that fees should not be used as a bar to people obtaining information to which they are entitled. Clearly, it is not being used as a revenue measure because in the last year 33,000 requests were made at a cost of $12.7 million. The retrieval figure was only half a million dollars. It is being used to bar or contain requests for information. The Australian Democrats will support the amendment.

—It is worth repeating, very briefly, the points made at the second reading stage. It is not that the coalition thinks the Freedom of Information Act is working perfectly. It does not. But we believe a $100 cap is simply unrealistic, given the extraordinary cost of some requests. We also do not believe that, with all the other access parliamentarians have to information, we should necessarily have—as a right—free access under freedom of information. For those reasons we will not support these amendments. It does not mean that at a later stage we will not work with the Greens and others to improve the operation of the act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government also opposes the amendments. Given the lateness of the hour, I will not go into great depth in rebutting them, other than to say that we also think the provisions that apply at the moment strike a balance. There are provisions that provide for financial hardship, public interest and other such criteria under the legislation. Accordingly, we oppose the Greens' amendment.

—Naturally the government wants to oppose the provisions. Why would it not? It wants to sit on the information that it has. It does not want to allow people to obtain information without too much cost. The government does not want members of parliament to have the information free of charge. What happens in the Congress in the United States of America? Is there any charge? Members of Congress can go to any department, demand to look at files and extract information from them in a whole range of areas—trade, environment and various others.

PARA.TAB: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us compare our situation with that of the United States senators and congressmen. Quite frankly, I cannot understand why, in opposition, Senator Vanstone would oppose a proposal for a person holding office as a member of the parliament to be exempt from paying any such charge. I heard what Senator Vanstone said in her speech during the second reading stage. I was appalled that she was saying, `Yes, it is a cost to the taxpayer'.

PARA.TAB: If those opposite take that view, we might as well abolish the parliament. This is a cost to the taxpayer, yes, but one of our main functions is to audit and control the actions of the executive government. How can we undertake that function if we are kept in ignorance—if individuals such as myself have to pay considerable amounts for freedom of information material? Not only do we have to pay considerable amounts for election campaigns but once having got here we would also have to pay considerable amounts for freedom of information requests. We cannot afford to do that and so we leave it to go by the board. Or we ask questions in estimates committee hearings and departmental officials make us fish in other pools. That is what happens.

It may be that Senator Vanstone and the opposition see themselves in government at some stage and this might be an embarrassment to them. It might be too much of a problem for members of parliament to obtain freedom of information free of charge on behalf of their constituents. But we do not write off for freedom of information requests just for the hell of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one suggests they did.

—We do not write off for freedom of information requests capriciously, we consider these matters. We do not just ask for heaps of information from the government departments because all our files would be filled up—like mine are after so many years, so much so that I will have to move out of my office soon. However, every honourable member and senator has a responsibility to be fully informed. I believe, and I am quite convinced of this, that the financial impost on parliamentarians in obtaining information would considerably restrict us in exercising our audit and control function. I strongly support the amendment moved by Senator Margetts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rarely speak on a third reading of a bill, but I do so on the occasion of the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill because I feel very strongly about the matter with which we have been recently dealing in the committee stage. PARA.TAB: For example, a lot of work is done in government departments on particular policy issues which are not necessarily the policy issues of the government. It would save an enormous amount of time and expense on behalf of the members of parliament, and the parliamentary library, if at least we knew what file titles there were in the various government departments. TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator Harradine has said. The Australian Democrats believe that the information that is being compiled in government departments should be available to members of parliament. We will be supporting his requests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on a matter which was raised in question time. I asked a question which related very closely to the fact that residues of DDT have been identified in beef carcasses in Australia. Therefore, the question again arises as to the purity of the product which we produce from our farming country—
—What!

—I hear some amazement from the floor of the Senate. A senator is not aware of that. It is a matter that senators should be aware of because it directly affects our capacity to trade internationally. An article in the Queensland Country Life of 14 October this year headed `DDT residue puts feedlot in quarantine' stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A Calliope district property, operating an approved drought "opportunity" feedlot, was quarantined . . .

That is a matter which I think Queensland senators, at least, should be aware of and concerned about. That is why I comment on it briefly in the Senate tonight. In response to my question, Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, was quite right to suggest that the detection of DDT in the carcasses proves that the detection system works. That is a very important thing to note, but that does not mean that we should be flippant about the opportunity that we need to take to ensure that this detection scheme continues.

PARA.TAB: The worst aspect of the minister's answer was the suggestion that the consumption of the meat involved would have had negligible effect on the consumers. The minister cannot be certain of that. It is an opinion. Even if it is somebody else's opinion, I think it is not a responsible action for the minister to take to relay such opinions as if they were fact.

What is wrong with this whole area is that opinions are expressed, such as `this matter will not hurt you', `that substance will not hurt you' and `you can consume that without any significant harm'. These are opinions, and they are based on short-term experience with a herbicide or a pesticide. The fact—not the opinion—is that DDT has been prohibited in Australia since 1987, and for good reason. Extensive tests have identified it as a carcinogen. That is not an effect which is necessarily or immediately apparent. Unqualified people would be readily able to say, `You can digest that stuff. Look at me, I've had some of it pass my lips and it hasn't hurt me'. That is the sort of thing we hear.

As a carcinogen, of course, the effect may be 20 or 30 years down the track. Those instant experts may become less apparent on our landscape—in fact, they may be underneath our landscape—as a result of their opinions, ignoring the facts. The fact is that DDT has been prohibited since 1987, and with good reason. The use of DDT has been prohibited, and rightly so, without qualification.

If currency is given to the idea that small amounts will not hurt us, the grazing on contaminated lands will be extended. The other thing that will be extended is the opportunity for people to be affected by consuming affected produce. That is an important aspect, and that is why I wanted to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the minister contributed to the myth that the consumption of small amounts will not hurt us. That is why I will persist in raising this matter and asking for proper action to recognise the threat that such a flippancy brings to the success of our rural industries.

The imperfections, the residues and the chemical traces that are in our produce are the very matters which other countries use to prohibit the importation of Australian produce. This is the very matter which we should guard against. We have the capacity to understand exactly where contaminated lands are. We have the capacity to manage our agricultural activities so that those contaminated lands are not used for grazing. Even though on 8 September the new chair of the National Registration Authority, Professor Ben Selinger, warned that land which had been used for canegrowing should not be used for beef grazing and that it would have the very effect which some 10 days later was identified in Queensland, the minister's reaction was `a little bit doesn't really hurt you; it doesn't matter that much'.

I endorse the warnings of Professor Sellinger and I urge the government to take notice of the chair of the National Registration Authority, the very body which should have the capacity to advise government to take care in these issues. I will not delay the Senate any longer. I just wanted to raise this matter. I could go on and quote extensively from the media material which has been around this particular incident but I am sure that those honourable senators who are interested in it will take the trouble to read the transcripts of the media reports of the matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 27 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the best estimate of the number of Australian women who have breast implants.
(2) What is the best estimate of the percentage of these women who have saline implants fitted.
(3) What is the best estimate of the percentage of these women who have silicone implants fitted.
(4) What amount of Commonwealth funding has been spent over each of the financial years 1991-92 and 1992-93 on medical research into the health risks associated with breast implants.
(5) What amount of Commonwealth funding will be spent over the 1993-94 financial year on medical research into the health risks associated with breast implants.

(6) What is the nature of the medical research produced or commissioned by the department into the health risks associated with breast implants and has any research been conducted into the possible link between breast implants and young children with malfunctioning immune systems; if so, please provide copies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The best estimate is between 30,000 and 50,000. Some estimates have put the number as high as 100,000, but there is no way to determine a more precise figure.
(2) Until the withdrawal of silicone gel filled breast implants on 8 January 1992 approximately 20 to 30 percent of implants were saline filled.
(3) Approximately 70 to 80 percent of women who sought breast implants used silicone gel filled breast prostheses prior to 8 January 1992.
(4) I am advised that there was no Commonwealth funding over the 1991-92 and 1992-93 financial years for medical research into the health risks associated with breast implants.
(5) I am advised that no Commonwealth funding has been allocated over the 1993-94 financial year for medical research into the health risks associated with breast implants.

ANSWER.PARA: The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) would be happy to consider support for research into the risks associated with breast implants, should applications with adequate scientific merit be received from appropriately qualified applicants.

PARA.TAB: (6) As outlined in response to the previous two questions, I am advised that no research has been produced or commissioned by the Department into health risks associated with breast implants nor any link between breast implants and young children with malfunctioning immune systems.
